revision.comment: /* Sir Thomas More (1592–1595; Shakespeare's involvement, 1603–1604) */ unknown
revision.text:
{{short description|possible order of composition of Shakespeare's plays}} {{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} [[File:Malone Attempt title page, cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Edmond Malone]] was the first scholar to construct a tentative chronology of Shakespeare's plays in ''An Attempt to Ascertain the Order in Which the Plays attributed to Shakspeare were Written'' (1778), an essay published in the second edition of [[Samuel Johnson]] and [[George Steevens]]' ''[[The Plays of William Shakespeare]]''.]] This article presents a possible '''''chronological listing of the composition of the [[Shakespeare's plays|plays]] of [[William Shakespeare]]'''''.
Shakespearean scholars, beginning with [[Edmond Malone]] in 1778, have attempted to reconstruct the relative chronology of Shakespeare's ''oeuvre'' by various means, using external evidence (such as references to the plays by Shakespeare's contemporaries in both critical material and private documents, allusions in other plays, entries in the [[Stationers' Register]], and records of performance and publication), and internal evidence (allusions within the plays to contemporary events, composition and publication dates of sources used by Shakespeare, stylistic analysis looking at the development of his style and diction over time, and the plays' context in the contemporary theatrical and literary ''[[milieu]]''). Most modern chronologies are based on the work of [[E. K. Chambers|E.K. Chambers]] in "The Problem of Chronology" (1930), published in his book ''William Shakespeare: A Study of Facts and Problems, Vol. I''.
== Introduction == Since the surviving evidence is fragmentary, there is not, neither can there be a definitive or precise chronology. Performance history is often of limited use, as the first recorded performance of many plays was not necessarily when that play was first performed. For example, the first recorded performance of ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' was not until 1662, yet we know the play was performed in Shakespeare's lifetime.<ref name="Levinson 70-71">{{cite book | editor-last=Levenson| editor-first=Jill L. | title=Romeo and Juliet | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2000 | pages=70–71 | isbn=978-0-19-953589-7}}</ref> Thus, performance history reveals little about the date of composition.
Similarly, dates of first publication are often relatively useless in determining a chronology, as roughly half the plays were not published until seven years after Shakespeare's death, in the ''[[First Folio]]'' (1623), prepared by [[John Heminges]] and [[Henry Condell]], and published by [[Edward Blount]], [[William Jaggard]] and Isaac Jaggard. Performance dates and publication dates are also problematic insofar as many of the plays were performed several years before they were published. For example, ''[[Titus Andronicus]]'' was performed in 1592, but not published until 1594, ''[[Othello]]'' was performed in 1604 but not published until 1622, ''[[King Lear]]'' was performed in 1606 but not published until 1608. Performance and publication dates can thus be used only to determine terminal dates of composition, with the initial dates often remaining so much more speculative.<ref>{{cite book | last=Chambers | first=E.K. | authorlink=E. K. Chambers | title=William Shakespeare: A Study of Facts and Problems, Vol. I | location=Oxford | publisher=Clarendon | year=1930 | page=[https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp/page/n284 245] | url=https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | isbn=978-0-19-811773-5 | accessdate=26 October 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150909142016/https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | archivedate=9 September 2015 | url-status=dead }}</ref>
In addition, some scholars dissent from the conventional dating system altogether. A notable scholar to do so is [[E. A. J. Honigmann]], who has attempted to push back the beginning of Shakespeare's career four or five years to the mid-1580s, with his "early start" theory. Honigmann argues that Shakespeare began his career with ''Titus Andronicus'' in 1586 (the conventional school of thought is that Shakespeare began writing plays upon arriving in London ''c.''1590).<ref>{{cite book | last=Honigmann | first=E.A.J. | authorlink=E. A. J. Honigmann | title=Shakespeare's Impact on his Contemporaries | location=London | publisher=Macmillan | year=1982 | isbn=978-0-389-20108-3 | url-access=registration | url=https://archive.org/details/shakespearesimpa0000honi }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last=Honigmann | first=E.A.J. | authorlink=E. A. J. Honigmann | title=Shakespeare: The 'Lost Years' | location=Manchester | publisher=Manchester University Press | year=1998 | origyear=1985 | edition=2nd | isbn=978-0-7190-5425-9}}</ref> Most scholars, however, adhere to a more orthodox chronology,<ref>{{cite book | last=Schoone-Jongen | first=Terence G. | title=Shakespeare's Companies: William Shakespeare's Early Career and the Acting Companies, 1577–1594 | location=Surrey | publisher=Ashgate | year=2008 | pages=17–42 | isbn=978-0-7546-6434-5}}</ref> and some, such as [[Gary Taylor (scholar)|Gary Taylor]] and Sidney Thomas, argue that the early start theory causes more problems than it solves.<ref>{{cite book | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | chapter=The Canon and Chronology of Shakespeare's Plays | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | title=William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1997 | edition=Revised | origyear=1987 | page=97 | isbn=978-0-393-31667-4}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last=Thomas | first=Sidney | title=On the Dating of Shakespeare's Early Plays | journal=[[Shakespeare Quarterly]] | volume=39 | issue=2 | date=Summer 1988 | pages=187–194 | jstor=2870629 | doi=10.2307/2870629}} {{subscription required}}</ref>
== Scholarship ==
=== E.K. Chambers === The chronology presented by [[E. K. Chambers|E.K. Chambers]] in 1930 is as follows:<ref>{{cite book | last=Chambers | first=E.K. | authorlink=E. K. Chambers | title=William Shakespeare: A Study of Facts and Problems, Vol. I | location=Oxford | publisher=Clarendon | year=1930 | pages=[https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp/page/n309 270]–271 | url=https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | isbn=978-0-19-811773-5 | accessdate=26 October 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150909142016/https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | archivedate=9 September 2015 | url-status=dead }}</ref> {{Div col|colwidth=40em}} * ''[[Henry VI, Part 2]]'' (1590–1591) * ''[[Henry VI, Part 3]]'' (1590–1591) * ''[[Henry VI, Part 1]]'' (1591–1592) * ''[[Richard III (play)|Richard III]]'' (1592–1593) * ''[[The Comedy of Errors]]'' (1592–1593) * ''[[Titus Andronicus]]'' (1593–1594) * ''[[The Taming of the Shrew]]'' (1593–1594) * ''[[The Two Gentlemen of Verona]]'' (1594–1595) * ''[[Love's Labour's Lost]]'' (1594–1595) * ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' (1594–1595) * ''[[Richard II (play)|Richard II]]'' (1595–1596) * ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]'' (1595–1596) * ''[[King John (play)|King John]]'' (1596–1597) * ''[[The Merchant of Venice]]'' (1596–1597) * ''[[Henry IV, Part 1]]'' (1597–1598) * ''[[Henry IV, Part 2]]'' (1597–1598) * ''[[Much Ado About Nothing]]'' (1598–1599) * ''[[Henry V (play)|Henry V]]'' (1598–1599) * ''[[Julius Caesar (play)|Julius Caesar]]'' (1599–1600) * ''[[As You Like It]]'' (1599–1600) * ''[[Twelfth Night]]'' (1599–1600) * ''[[Hamlet]]'' (1600–1601) * ''[[The Merry Wives of Windsor]]'' (1600–1601) * ''[[Troilus and Cressida]]'' (1601–1602) * ''[[All's Well That Ends Well]]'' (1602–1603) * ''[[Measure for Measure]]'' (1604–1605) * ''[[Othello]]'' (1604–1605) * ''[[King Lear]]'' (1605–1606) * ''[[Macbeth]]'' (1605–1606) * ''[[Antony and Cleopatra]]'' (1606–1607) * ''[[Coriolanus]]'' (1607–1608) * ''[[Timon of Athens]]'' (1607–1608) * ''[[Pericles, Prince of Tyre]]'' (1608–1609) * ''[[Cymbeline]]'' (1609–1610) * ''[[The Winter's Tale]]'' (1610–1611) * ''[[The Tempest]]'' (1611–1612) * ''[[Henry VIII (play)|Henry VIII]]'' (1612–1613) * ''[[The Two Noble Kinsmen]]'' (1612–1613) {{div col end}}
=== Modern ''Complete Works'' === There are six major modern scholarly editions of the ''[[Complete Works of Shakespeare]]'': * ''The [[Riverside Shakespeare]]'' (edited by [[G. Blakemore Evans]] in 1974, with a second edition in 1996) * ''[[The Oxford Shakespeare]]: The Complete Works'' (edited by [[Stanley Wells]], [[Gary Taylor (scholar)|Gary Taylor]], [[John Jowett]] and [[William Montgomery (English literature scholar)|William Montgomery]] in 1986, with a second edition in 2005) * ''The [[W. W. Norton & Company|Norton]] Shakespeare: Based on the Oxford Edition'' (edited by [[Stephen Greenblatt]], [[Walter Cohen]], [[Jean E. Howard]] and [[Katharine Eisaman Maus]] in 1997, with a second edition in 2008) * ''[[Arden Shakespeare|The Arden Shakespeare: Complete Works]]'' (edited by [[Richard Proudfoot]], [[Ann Thompson (scholar)|Ann Thompson]] and [[David Scott Kastan]] in 1998, with a second edition in 2002 and a third in 2011) * ''The Complete [[Pelican Books|Pelican]] Shakespeare'' (edited by [[Stephen Orgel]] and [[A. R. Braunmuller]] in 2002), and * ''[[Royal Shakespeare Company|The RSC Shakespeare: Complete Works]]'' (edited by [[Jonathan Bate]] and [[Eric Rasmussen (scholar)|Eric Rasmussen]] in 2007).
Additionally, as with Oxford, Arden, Pelican and the RSC, the [[New Cambridge Shakespeare]], the New [[Penguin Books|Penguin]] Shakespeare, the [[New American Library|Signet]] Classic Shakespeare, the [[J. Dover Wilson|Dover Wilson]] Shakespeare, the Shakespeare Folios and the [[Folger Shakespeare Library]] all publish scholarly editions of individual plays, although none have issued a complete works volume.
''Arden'' presents the plays alphabetically without any attempt to construct an overall chronology. ''Oxford'', ''Riverside'', ''Norton'' and ''RSC'' all present chronologies which differ from one another and which attempt to construct only approximate dating. The following list is based on that of ''The Oxford Shakespeare: The Complete Works'' (2nd ed.) and the accompanying ''William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion'' (Revised ed.), edited by Stanley Wells and Gary Taylor. However, none of the major chronologies has any real authority over any of the others.
== Chronology ==
=== ''[[The Two Gentlemen of Verona]]'' (1589–1591) === [[File:Palladis Tamia, Wits Treasury Francis Meres Love labours won excerpt 1598.jpg|thumb|upright|Extract from [[Francis Meres]]' ''[[Palladis Tamia]]'' (1598), which makes reference to twelve of Shakespeare's plays.]] :'''''First official record''''': in [[Francis Meres]]' ''[[Palladis Tamia]]'' (1598), referred to as "''Gentlemen of Verona''." :'''''First published''''': ''First Folio'' (1623). :'''''First recorded performance''''': an adaptation by [[Benjamin Victor (theatre manager)|Benjamin Victor]] was performed at [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane|Drury Lane]] in 1762.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Warren | editor-first=Roger | title=The Two Gentlemen of Verona | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2008 | page=1 | isbn=978-0-19-283142-2}}</ref> The earliest known performance of the straight Shakespearean text was at [[Royal Opera House|Covent Garden]] on 15 April 1784, although because of the reference to the play in ''Palladis Tamia'', we know it was definitely performed in Shakespeare's lifetime.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Schlueter | editor-first=Kurt | title=The Two Gentlemen of Verona | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=1990 | page=22 | isbn=978-0-521-18169-3}}</ref> :'''''Evidence''''': Stanley Wells argues that the play's "dramatic structure is comparatively unambitious, and while some of its scenes are expertly constructed, those involving more than, at the most, four characters betray an uncertainty of technique suggestive of inexperience."<ref>{{cite book | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | editor3-last=Jowett | editor3-first=John | editor3-link=John Jowett | editor4-last=Montgomery | editor4-first=William | title=The Oxford Shakespeare: The Complete Works | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2005 | edition=2nd | origyear=1986 | page=[https://archive.org/details/completeworks0000shak_f0m2/page/1 1] | isbn=978-0-19-926718-7 | url=https://archive.org/details/completeworks0000shak_f0m2/page/1 }}</ref> The play is therefore considered one of the first Shakespeare composed after his arrival in London ''c.''1590, at which point he would have lacked theatrical experience. Furthermore, the discussion between Launce and Speed regarding the vices and virtues of Launce's mistress (3.1.276-359<ref>For each play, line references, and occasionally even scene numbers and divisions, can differ substantially from edition to edition. In order to maintain a degree of continuity, all line references throughout this article are to the individual Oxford Shakespeare editions, unless otherwise noted.</ref>) seems to borrow from [[John Lyly]]'s ''[[Midas (Lyly play)|Midas]]'', which was written in late 1588 and/or early 1589, thus fixing a ''[[terminus post quem]]'' for the play.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Warren | editor-first=Roger | title=The Two Gentlemen of Verona | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2008 | pages=20, 25–27 | isbn=978-0-19-283142-2}}</ref> This situates the date of composition as somewhere between 1589 and 1591, by which time it is known Shakespeare was working on the ''Henry VI'' plays.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Leech | editor-first=Clifford | editor-link=Clifford Leech | title=The Two Gentlemen of Verona | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Second Series | year=1969 | pages=[https://archive.org/details/twogentlemenofve00shak_3/page/ xxx–xxxiv] | isbn=978-0-17-443581-5 | url=https://archive.org/details/twogentlemenofve00shak_3/page/ }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Carroll | editor-first=William C. | title=The Two Gentlemen of Verona | location=London | publisher=Thompson Learning | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2004 | pages=116–130 | isbn=978-1-903436-95-0}}</ref> In his 2008 edition of the play for the Oxford Shakespeare, Roger Warren, following E.A.J. Honigmann, suggests Shakespeare may have written the play prior to his arrival in London, possibly as early as 1587, although he acknowledges this theory is purely speculative.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Warren | editor-first=Roger | title=The Two Gentlemen of Verona | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2008 | pages=23–25 | isbn=978-0-19-283142-2}}</ref>
=== ''[[The Taming of the Shrew]]'' (1590–1591) === [[File:A Shrew TP 1596.jpg|thumb|upright=0.70|1596 second quarto of ''A Shrew'']] :'''''First official record''''': possible version of the play entered into [[Stationers' Register]] by [[Peter Short (printer)|Peter Short]] on 2 May 1594 as "a booke intituled A plesant Conceyted historie called the Tayminge of a Shrowe." First record of the play as it exists today is found in the ''First Folio'' (1623). :'''''First published''''': possible version of the play published in [[quarto]] in 1594 as ''A Pleasant Conceited Historie, called The taming of a Shrew'' (printed by Peter Short for [[Cuthbert Burby]]). This text was republished in 1596 (again by Short for Burby) and 1607 (by [[Valentine Simmes]] for [[Nicholas Ling]]). The play as it exists today was first published in the ''First Folio'' as ''The Taming of the Shrew''. :'''''Additional information (publication)''''': there is a general lack of scholarly agreement regarding the exact relationship between the 1594 ''A Shrew'' and the 1623 ''The Shrew''. Originally, ''A Shrew'' was seen as a non-Shakespearean source for ''The Shrew'', meaning ''The Shrew'' must have been completed sometime after 2 May 1594.<ref>{{cite book | last=Chambers | first=E.K. | authorlink=E. K. Chambers | title=William Shakespeare: A Study of Facts and Problems, Vol. I | location=Oxford | publisher=Clarendon | year=1930 | pages=[https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp/page/n364 323]–328 | url=https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | isbn=978-0-19-811773-5 | accessdate=26 October 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150909142016/https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | archivedate=9 September 2015 | url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last=Shroeder | first=John W. | title= ''The Taming of a Shrew'' and ''The Taming of the Shrew'': A Case Reopened | journal=[[Journal of English and Germanic Philology]] | volume=57 | issue=3 | date=October 1958 | pages=424–443 | jstor=27707121 }} {{subscription required}}</ref> This remained the predominant theory until 1850, when Samuel Hickson suggested that ''A Shrew'' was in some way derived from ''The Shrew''.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Hickson | first=Samuel | title=Marlowe and the old ''Taming of the Shrew'' | journal=[[Notes and Queries|Notes & Queries]] | volume=15 | date=9 February 1850 | pages=226–227 | url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/11929/11929-h/11929-h.htm | accessdate=19 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last=Hickson | first=Samuel | title=''The Taming of the Shrew'' | journal=[[Notes and Queries|Notes & Queries]] | volume=22 | date=30 March 1850 | pages=345–347 | url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/12198/12198-h/12198-h.htm | accessdate=15 July 2014}}</ref> Peter Alexander developed Hickson's work into his [[memorial reconstruction|reported text]]/[[bad quarto]] theory, which necessitates that ''The Shrew'' must have been written prior to 2 May 1594.<ref>{{cite news | last=Alexander | first=Peter | title=''The Taming of the Shrew'' | newspaper=[[The Times Literary Supplement]] | date=16 September 1926}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last=Alexander | first=Peter | title=The Original Ending of ''The Taming of the Shrew'' | journal=[[Shakespeare Quarterly]] | volume=20 | issue=1 | date=Spring 1969 | pages=111–116 | jstor=2868994 | doi=10.2307/2868994}} {{subscription required}}</ref> However, there are other theories about the relationship between the texts. In 1942, R.A. Houk posited the "''[[Ur-Hamlet|Ur-Shrew]]''" theory, suggesting that the plays are two completely unrelated texts by different authors based on the same (now lost) source.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Houk | first=R.A. | title=The Evolution of ''The Taming of the Shrew'' | journal=[[Modern Language Association|PMLA]] | volume=57 | issue=4 | date=Winter 1942 | pages=1009–1038 | jstor=458874 | doi=10.2307/458874}} {{subscription required}}</ref> In 1943, G.I. Duthie refined this theory, suggesting that ''A Shrew'' was a reported text of an early draft of ''The Shrew''.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Duthie | first=G.I. | title=''The Taming of a Shrew'' and ''The Taming of the Shrew'' | journal=[[The Review of English Studies]] | volume=19 | issue=76 | date=October 1943 | pages=337–356 | url=http://res.oxfordjournals.org/content/os-XIX/76/337 | accessdate=26 October 2014 | doi=10.1093/res/os-XIX.76.337}} {{subscription required}}</ref> In his 1998 edition of ''A Shrew'' for the New Cambridge Shakespeare: The Early Quartos series, Stephen Roy Miller suggested ''A Shrew'' was an adaptation of ''The Shrew'' written by someone other than Shakespeare.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Miller | editor-first=Stephen Roy | title=The Taming of a Shrew: The 1594 Quarto | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare: The Early Quartos | year=1998 | pages=1–57 | isbn=978-0-521-08796-4}}</ref> Critics remain divided on this issue.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Morris | editor-first=Brian | editor-link=Brian Morris, Baron Morris of Castle Morris | title=The Taming of the Shrew | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Second Series | year=1981 | pages=12–50 | isbn=978-1-903436-10-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Oliver | editor-first=H.J. | title=The Taming of the Shrew | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=1982 | pages=13–34 | isbn=978-0-19-953652-8}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Miller | editor-first=Stephen Roy | title=The Taming of a Shrew: The 1594 Quarto | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare: The Early Quartos | year=1998 | pages=31–34 | isbn=978-0-521-08796-4}}</ref><ref>{{cite book| editor-last=Hodgdon | editor-first=Barbara | title= The Taming of the Shrew | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2010 | pages=18–23 | isbn=978-1-903436-93-6}}</ref> :'''''First recorded performance''''': according to [[Philip Henslowe]]'s diary, a play called ''The Tamynge of A Shrowe'' was performed at [[Newington Butts#Theatre|Newington Butts]] on 11 June 1594. This could have been either the 1594 ''A Shrew'' or the Shakespearean ''The Shrew'', but as the [[Admiral's Men]] and the [[Lord Chamberlain's Men]], Shakespeare's own company, were sharing the theatre at the time, and, thus, Shakespeare himself was probably there, scholars tend to assume that it was ''The Shrew''<ref>{{cite book| editor-last=Hodgdon | editor-first=Barbara | title= The Taming of the Shrew | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2010 | page=14 | isbn=978-1-903436-93-6}}</ref> The Shakespearean version was definitely performed at [[Court (royal)|court]] before [[Charles I of England|Charles I]] and [[Henrietta Maria of France|Henrietta Maria]] on 26 November 1633, where it was described as "likt."<!--not a typo--><ref>{{cite book| editor-last=Hodgdon | editor-first=Barbara | title= The Taming of the Shrew | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2010 | page=16 | isbn=978-1-903436-93-6}}</ref> :'''''Evidence''''': a ''terminus ante quem'' for ''A Shrew'' would seem to be August 1592; a stage direction at 3.21 mentions "Simon," which probably refers to the actor Simon Jewell, who was buried on 21 August 1592.<ref name="Taylor 110">{{cite book | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | chapter=The Canon and Chronology of Shakespeare's Plays | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | title=William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1997 | edition=Revised | origyear=1987 | page=110 | isbn=978-0-393-31667-4}}</ref> ''The Shrew'' must have been written earlier than 1593, as [[Anthony Chute]]'s ''Beauty Dishonoured, written under the title of Shore's wife'' (published in June 1593) contains the line "He calls his Kate, and she must come and kiss him." This must refer to ''The Shrew'', as there is no corresponding "kissing scene" in ''A Shrew''.<ref name="Taylor 110" /> There are also verbal similarities between both ''Shrew'' plays and the anonymous play ''[[A Knack To Know A Knave|A Knack to Know a Knave]]'' (first performed in June 1592). ''Knack'' features several passages common to both ''A Shrew'' and ''The Shrew'', but it also borrows several passages unique to ''The Shrew''. This suggests ''The Shrew'' was on stage prior to June 1592.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Thompson| editor-first=Ann | title=The Taming of the Shrew | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=2003 | edition=Revised | origyear=1984 | pages=1–4 | isbn=9789812836540}}</ref> However, Kier Elam further narrows the terminal date of ''The Shrew'' to 1591, based on Shakespeare's probable use of two sources published that year; [[Abraham Ortelius]]' map of Italy in the fourth edition of ''[[Theatrum Orbis Terrarum]]'' and [[John Florio]]'s ''Second Fruits''.<ref>{{cite book | last=Elam | first=Kier | chapter='At the cubiculo': Shakespeare's Problems with Italian Language and Culture | editor-last=Marrapodi | editor-first=Michele | title=Italian Culture in the Drama of Shakespeare & his Contemporaries: Rewriting, Remaking, Refashioning | location=Aldershot | publisher=Ashgate | year=2007 | pages=99–110 | series=Anglo-Italian Renaissance Studies | isbn=978-0-7546-5504-6}}</ref> As neither ''Shrew'' play is likely to have been written any earlier than 1590,<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Thompson| editor-first=Ann | title=The Taming of the Shrew | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=2003 | edition=Revised | origyear=1984 | page=3 | isbn=9789812836540}}</ref> this places the likely date of composition of ''The Shrew'' as 1590–1591, with ''A Shrew'' written sometime prior to August 1592.
=== ''[[Henry VI, Part 2]]'' (1591) === [[File:Henry VI pt 2 quarto.jpg|thumb|upright=0.70|1594 quarto of ''The First part of the Contention'']] :'''''First official record''''': version of the play entered into the Stationers' Register by [[Thomas Millington (publisher)|Thomas Millington]] on 12 March 1594 as "a booke intituled, the firste parte of the Contention of the twoo famous houses of York and Lancaster with the deathe of the good Duke Humfrey and the banishement and Deathe of the Duke of Suffolk and the tragicall ende of the prowd Cardinall of Winchester, with the notable rebellion of Jack Cade and the Duke of Yorkes ffirste<!--not a typo--> clayme unto the Crowne." :'''''First published''''': version of the play published in quarto in 1594 as ''The First part of the Contention betwixt the two famous Houses of Yorke and Lancaster, with the death of the good Duke Humphrey: And the banishment and death of the Duke of Suffolke, and the Tragicall end of the proud Cardinal of Winchester, with the notable Rebellion of Jack Cade: and the Duke of Yorke's first claim unto the Crowne'' (printed by [[Thomas Creede]] for Thomas Millington). This text was republished in 1600 (by Valentine Simmes for Millington) and in 1619. The 1619 text was printed with the 1595 [[octavo]] of ''[[Henry VI, Part 3]]'' under the title ''The Whole Contention betweene the two Famous Houses, Lancaster and Yorke. With the Tragicall ends of the good Duke Humfrey, Richard Duke of Yorke, and King Henrie the sixt'', as part of William Jaggard's "[[False Folio]]" (printed by [[Thomas Pavier]]). The 1623 ''Folio'' text of ''2 Henry VI'' appears under the title ''The second Part of Henry the Sixt, with the death of the Good Duke Humfrey''. :'''''Additional information (publication)''''': scholars are undecided as to the exact nature of the relationship between the 1594 ''The Contention'' and the 1623 ''2 Henry VI''. There are four main theories: ''The Contention'' is a bad quarto, a reported text constructed from memory based upon a performance of ''2 Henry VI''; ''The Contention'' is an early draft of ''2 Henry VI''; ''The Contention'' is both a bad quarto ''and'' an early draft (i.e. a reported text based upon a staging of an early draft of the play); ''The Contention'' is an anonymous source for ''2 Henry VI''. Originally, the bad quarto theory was generally accepted by scholars. First suggested by [[Samuel Johnson]] in the original edition of ''[[The Plays of William Shakespeare]]'' (1765), it remained the predominant theory until challenged by [[Edmond Malone]] in ''The Plays and Poems of William Shakespeare'' (1790), favouring the early draft theory. In 1929, Peter Alexander and [[Madeleine Doran]] re-established the dominance of the bad quarto theory.<ref name="Alexander">{{cite book | last=Alexander | first=Peter | title=Shakespeare's Henry VI and Richard III | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | year=1929 | isbn=978-0-8492-0114-1}}</ref><ref name="Doran">{{cite book | last=Doran | first=Madeleine | authorlink=Madeleine Doran | title=Henry VI, Parts II and III: Their Relation to the Contention and the True Tragedy | location=Iowa, IA | publisher=University of Iowa Press | year=1928 | isbn=978-0-8482-0606-2}}</ref> Scholars have continued to debate the issue since then, with no real consensus reached.<ref name="Urkowitz">{{cite journal | last=Urkowitz | first=Steven | title="If I mistake in those foundations which I build upon": Peter Alexander's textual analysis of ''Henry VI Parts 2 and 3'' | journal=[[English Literary Renaissance]] | volume=18 | issue=2 |date=March 1988 | pages=230–256 | doi=10.1111/j.1475-6757.1988.tb00954.x}} {{subscription required}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last=Warren | first=Roger | title=The Quarto and Folio Texts of ''2 Henry VI'': A Reconsideration | journal=[[The Review of English Studies]] | volume=51 | issue=202 | date=May 2000 | pages=193–207 | url=http://res.oxfordjournals.org/content/51/202/193.abstract | accessdate=26 October 2014 | doi=10.1093/res/51.202.193}} {{subscription required}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Warren | editor-first=Roger | title=Henry VI, Part Two | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2003 | pages=78–87 | isbn=978-0-19-953742-6}}</ref> The source theory, originated by [[Georg Gottfried Gervinus]] in 1849 has fallen out of favour in the twentieth and twentieth-first centuries.<ref name="Knowles 37-39">{{cite book | editor-last=Knowles | editor-first=Ronald | title=King Henry VI Part 2 | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2001 | pages=37–39 | isbn=978-1-903436-63-9}}</ref> :'''''First recorded performance''''': although it is known that the play was definitely performed in Shakespeare's day, adaptations dominated the stage throughout the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. The earliest known such adaptation was in 1681, with [[John Crowne]]'s two-part play, ''Henry the Sixth, The First Part'' and ''The Misery of Civil War''.<ref name="Knowles 2-3">{{cite book | editor-last=Knowles | editor-first=Ronald | title=King Henry VI Part 2 | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2001 | pages=2–3 | isbn=978-1-903436-63-9}}</ref> Two more adaptations followed in 1723. The first was ''Humfrey Duke of Gloucester'' by [[Ambrose Philips]], the second was [[Theophilus Cibber]]'s ''King Henry VI: A Tragedy'', both of which adapted scenes from ''2 Henry VI''.<ref name="Warren 7">{{cite book | editor-last=Warren | editor-first=Roger | title=Henry VI, Part Two | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2003 | page=7 | isbn=978-0-19-953742-6}}</ref> Another adaptation followed in 1817, [[John Herman Merivale|J.H. Merivale]]'s ''Richard Duke of York; or the Contention of York and Lancaster'', which used material from all three ''Henry VI'' plays, but removed everything not directly related to [[Richard of York, 3rd Duke of York|York]].<ref name="Knowles 4-5">{{cite book | editor-last=Knowles | editor-first=Ronald | title=King Henry VI Part 2 | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2001 | pages=4–5 | isbn=978-1-903436-63-9}}</ref> The earliest known production of the Shakespearean ''2 Henry VI'' was on 23 April 1864 at the [[Surrey Theatre]], directed by [[James Robertson Anderson|James Anderson]].<ref name="Warren 7" /> :'''''Evidence''''': it is known that ''True Tragedy'' (i.e. ''3 Henry VI'') was on stage by June 1592. It is also known that ''True Tragedy'' was definitely a sequel to ''The Contention'', meaning ''The Contention'' must also have been on stage by early 1592 at the latest. It is also thought that ''[[Henry VI, Part 1]]'' was a new play in March 1592.<ref name="Taylor 1-10">{{cite book | editor-last=Taylor | editor-first=Michael | title=Henry VI, Part One | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2003 | pages=1–10 | isbn=978-0-19-953710-5}}</ref> If ''The Contention'' predates ''1 Henry VI'', the theatrical evidence would place the likely date of ''2 Henry VI'' as 1591.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Hattaway | editor-first=Martin | title=The Second Part of King Henry VI | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=1991 | pages=56–68 | isbn=978-0-521-37704-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Warren | editor-first=Roger | title=Henry VI, Part Two | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2003 | pages=60–74 | isbn=978-0-19-953742-6}}</ref>
=== ''[[Henry VI, Part 3]]'' (1591) === [[File:Groatsworth.jpg|thumb|upright=0.70|Title page of [[Robert Greene (dramatist)|Robert Green]]'s ''[[Greene's Groats-Worth of Wit|Groatsworth of Wit]]'', which helps fix a date for ''3 Henry VI''.]] :'''''First official record''''': version of the play published in octavo in 1595. ''3 Henry VI'' was never entered into the Stationers' Register.<ref>{{cite book | editor1-last=Cox | editor1-first=John D. | editor2-last=Rasmussen | editor2-first=Eric | title=King Henry VI Part 3 | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2001 | pages=150–151 | isbn=978-1-903436-31-8}}</ref> :'''''First published''''': version of the play published in octavo in 1595 as ''The True Tragedie of Richard Duke of Yorke, and the death of good King Henrie the Sixt, with the Whole Contention betweene the two Houses Lancaster and Yorke'' (printed by Peter Short for Thomas Millington). This text was republished in quarto in 1600 (by William White for Millington) and in 1619. The 1619 text was printed with the 1594 quarto of ''2 Henry VI'' under the title ''The Whole Contention betweene the two Famous Houses, Lancaster and Yorke. With the Tragicall ends of the good Duke Humfrey, Richard Duke of Yorke, and King Henrie the sixt'', as part of William Jaggard's "False Folio" (printed by Thomas Pavier). The 1623 ''Folio'' text of ''3 Henry VI'' appears under the title ''The third Part of Henry the Sixt, with the death of the Duke of Yorke''. :'''''Additional information (publication)''''': scholars are undecided as to the exact nature of the relationship between the 1595 ''True Tragedy'' and the 1623 ''3 Henry VI''. There are four main theories: ''True Tragedy'' is a "bad octavo", a reported text constructed from memory based upon a performance of ''3 Henry VI''; ''True Tragedy'' is an early draft of ''3 Henry VI''; ''True Tragedy'' is both a bad quarto ''and'' an early draft (i.e. a reported text based upon a staging of an early draft of the play); ''True Tragedy'' is an anonymous source for ''3 Henry VI''. Originally, the bad quarto theory was generally accepted by scholars. First suggested by Samuel Johnson in the original edition of ''The Plays of William Shakespeare'' (1765), it remained the predominant theory until challenged by Edmond Malone in ''The Plays and Poems of William Shakespeare'' (1790), favouring the early draft theory. In 1929, Peter Alexander and Madeleine Doran re-established the dominance of the bad quarto theory.<ref name="Alexander" /><ref name="Doran" /> Scholars have continued to debate the issue since then, with no real consensus reached.<ref name="Urkowitz" /><ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Martin | editor-first=Randall | title=Henry VI, Part Three | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2001 | pages=96–123 | isbn=978-0-19-953711-2}}</ref> The source theory, originated by Georg Gottfried Gervinus in 1849 has fallen out of favour in the twentieth and twentieth-first centuries.<ref name="Knowles 37-39" /> :'''''First recorded performance''''': although it is known that the play was definitely performed in Shakespeare's day, adaptations dominated the stage throughout the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. The earliest known such adaptation was in 1681, with John Crowne's two-part play, ''Henry the Sixth, The First Part'' and ''The Misery of Civil War''.<ref name="Knowles 2-3" /> In 1699, ''3 Henry VI'' was also partly incorporated into [[Colley Cibber]]'s ''[[Richard III (1699 play)|The Tragical History of King Richard the Third]]''.<ref>{{cite book | editor1-last=Cox | editor1-first=John D. | editor2-last=Rasmussen | editor2-first=Eric | title=King Henry VI Part 3 | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2001 | page=15 | isbn=978-1-903436-31-8}}</ref> In 1723, Theophilus Cibber's ''King Henry VI: A Tragedy'' also adapted scenes from ''3 Henry VI''.<ref name="Warren 7" /> Another adaptation followed in 1817, J.H. Merivale's ''Richard Duke of York; or the Contention of York and Lancaster'', which used material from all three ''Henry VI'' plays, but removed everything not directly related to York.<ref name="Knowles 4-5" /> The earliest known production of the Shakespearean ''3 Henry VI'' was on 4 May 1906 at the [[Royal Shakespeare Theatre|Shakespeare Memorial Theatre]], directed by [[Frank Benson (actor)|F.R. Benson]].<ref>{{cite book | editor1-last=Cox | editor1-first=John D. | editor2-last=Rasmussen | editor2-first=Eric | title=King Henry VI Part 3 | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2001 | page=16 | isbn=978-1-903436-31-8}}</ref> :'''''Evidence''''': in ''[[Greene's Groats-Worth of Wit|Groatsworth of Wit]]'', [[Robert Greene (dramatist)|Robert Greene]] writes about "an upstart crow, beautified with our feathers, that with his 'tiger's heart wrapped in a player's hide', supposes that he is as well able to bombast out a [[blank verse]] as the best of you, and being an absolute ''[[Jack of all trades, master of none|Johannes fac totum]]'', is in his own conceit the only Shake-scene in a country." Obviously directed at Shakespeare, this is a reference to a line in ''3 Henry VI'', when York refers to [[Margaret of Anjou|Margaret]] as a "tiger's heart wrapped in woman's hide" (1.4.137). As ''Groatsworth'' was registered in the Stationers' Register on 20 September 1592, this means that ''True Tragedy'' must have been on stage prior to 23 June 1592, as that was when the government shut the London theatres due to an outbreak of [[plague (disease)|plague]]. To have been on stage by June 1592, the play was most likely written sometime in 1591.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Hattaway | editor-first=Martin | title=The Third Part of King Henry VI | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=1993 | pages=52–60 | isbn=978-0-521-37705-8}}</ref><ref name="Martin 123-133">{{cite book | editor-last=Martin | editor-first=Randall | title=Henry VI, Part Three | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2001 | pages=123–133 | isbn=978-0-19-953711-2}}</ref>
=== ''[[Henry VI, Part 1]]'' (1591–1592) === :'''''First official record''''': possibly in Philip Henslowe's diary. On 3 March 1592, Henslowe reports seeing a "ne" play called "Harey the vj" (i.e. ''Henry VI''), which could be a reference to ''1 Henry VI'', although this is not universally accepted.<ref>{{cite book | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | chapter=The Canon and Chronology of Shakespeare's Plays | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | title=William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1997 | edition=Revised | origyear=1987 | page=89 | isbn=978-0-393-31667-4}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | first=Winifred | last=Frazer | title=Henslowe's "ne" | journal=[[Notes and Queries]] | volume=38 | issue=1 |date=March 1991 | pages=34–35 | doi=10.1093/nq/38.1.34}} {{subscription required}}</ref> An entry found in the Stationers' Register on 19 April 1602 transferring the rights from Thomas Millington to Thomas Pavier of "The first and Second parte of Henry VJ" is thought to refer to what we today call ''2 Henry VI'' and ''3 Henry VI'', not ''1 Henry VI''.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Martin | editor-first=Randall | title=Henry VI, Part Three | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2001 | page=104n1 | isbn=978-0-19-953711-2}}</ref> The first definite record of the play was not until the ''First Folio'' in 1623. :'''''First published''''': ''First Folio'' (1623), as ''The first Part of Henry the Sixt''. :'''''First recorded performance''''': possibly on 3 March 1592 at [[The Rose (theatre)|The Rose]], as seen by Philip Henslowe. The earliest definite performance was on 13 March 1738 at Covent Garden.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Hattaway | editor-first=Michael | title=The First Part of King Henry VI | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=1990 | page=[https://archive.org/details/firstpartofkingh0000shak/page/43 43] | isbn=978-0-521-29634-2 | url=https://archive.org/details/firstpartofkingh0000shak/page/43 }}</ref> :'''''Additional information (attribution)''''': many critics consider ''1 Henry VI'' to have been written as a prequel to the successful two-part play, ''The Contention'' and ''True Tragedy''.<ref name="Martin 123-133" /><ref>{{cite journal | last=McKerrow | first=R.B. | authorlink=Ronald Brunlees McKerrow | title=A Note on ''Henry VI, Part II'' and ''The Contention of York and Lancaster'' | journal=[[The Review of English Studies]] | volume=9 | issue=34 | date=April 1933 | pages=157–169 | url=http://res.oxfordjournals.org/content/os-IX/34/157 | accessdate=26 October 2014 | doi=10.1093/res/os-IX.34.157}} {{subscription required}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Burns | editor-first=Edward | title=King Henry VI Part 1 | location=London | publisher=Thompson Learning | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2000 | pages=67–90 | isbn=978-1-903436-43-1}}</ref> Possibly co-written with [[Thomas Nashe]] and/or other unidentified dramatists.<ref name="Taylor 1H6">{{cite journal | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | title=Shakespeare and Others: The Authorship of ''Henry the Sixth, Part One'' | journal=Medieval and Renaissance Drama | volume=7 |year=1995 | pages=145–205}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last=Vincent | first=Paul J. | title=Structuring and Revision in ''1 Henry VI'' | journal=[[Philological Quarterly]] | volume=84 | issue=4 | date=Fall 2005 | pages=377–402 | url=http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/27756375/structuring-revision-1-henry-vi | accessdate=15 July 2014}} {{subscription required}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last=Vickers | first=Brian | authorlink=Brian Vickers (literary scholar) | title=Incomplete Shakespeare: Or, Denying Coauthorship in ''1 Henry VI'' | journal=[[Shakespeare Quarterly]] | volume=58 | issue=3 | date=Fall 2007 | pages=311–352 | url=http://muse.jhu.edu/login?auth=0&type=summary&url=/journals/shakespeare_quarterly/v058/58.3vickers.html | accessdate=26 October 2014 | doi=10.1353/shq.2007.0053}} {{subscription required}}</ref> :'''''Evidence''''': on 3 March 1592, Philip Henslowe saw a new play called "Harey the vj" at The Rose, but he gives no further information. In August, Thomas Nashe published ''[[Pierce Penniless|Pierce Penniless, His Supplication to the Divell]]'', in which he refers to a play he had recently seen featuring a rousing depiction of [[John Talbot, 1st Earl of Shrewsbury|Lord Talbot]], a major character in ''1 Henry VI''. Most critics take Nashe's reference to Talbot as supportive of the fact that the play Henslowe saw was ''1 Henry VI''. If, then, it was a new play in March 1592, and if we also assume that it was a prequel written after the other two plays in the trilogy, the play was most likely written in 1591 or very early 1592.<ref name="Taylor 1-10" /><ref name="Taylor 1H6" />
=== ''[[Titus Andronicus]]'' (1591–1592) === [[File:Shakespeare Titus Andronicus Q1 1594.jpg|thumb|upright=0.70|1594 quarto of ''Titus Andronicus'']] :'''''First official record''''': Philip Henslowe's diary, 24 January 1594, where he records seeing the play "titus & ondronicus" at The Rose.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Bate | editor-first=Jonathan | editor-link=Jonathan Bate | title=Titus Andronicus | location=London | publisher=Routledge | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=1995 | pages=69–70 | isbn=978-1-903436-05-9}}</ref> :'''''First published''''': published in quarto in February 1594 as ''The Most Lamentable Romaine Tragedie of Titus Andronicus'', the first known printing of a Shakespearean play (printed by John Danter for Edward White and Thomas Millington). The play was republished in 1600 (printed by [[James Roberts (printer)|James Roberts]] for White) and 1611 (printed by [[Edward Allde]] for White). The ''Folio'' text appears under the title ''The Lamentable Tragedy of Titus Andronicus''. :'''''First recorded performance''''': on 24 January 1594 performed by [[Sussex's Men]] at The Rose, as recorded in Henslowe's diary.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Waith | editor-first=Eugene M. | title=Titus Andronicus | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=1984 | page=2 | isbn=978-0-19-953610-8}}</ref> :'''''Additional information (attribution)''''': ''Titus'' is most likely a [[Authorship of Titus Andronicus|collaboration]] between Shakespeare and at least one other dramatist, probably [[George Peele]].<ref>{{cite book | last=Tarlinskaja | first=Marina | authorlink=Marina Tarlinskaja | title=Shakespeare's Verse: Iambic Pentameter and the Poet's Idiosyncrasies | location=New York, NY | publisher=Peter Lang | series=American University Studies | year=1987 | isbn=978-0-8204-0344-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last=Jackson | first=MacDonald P. | authorlink=MacDonald P. Jackson | title=Stage Directions and Speech Headings in Act 1 of ''Titus Andronicus'' Q (1594): Shakespeare or Peele? | journal=Studies in Bibliography | volume=49 | year=1996 | pages=134–148 | url=http://xtf.lib.virginia.edu/xtf/view?docId=StudiesInBiblio/uvaBook/tei/sibv049.xml;chunk.id=vol049.06;toc.depth=1;toc.id=vol049.06;brand=default | accessdate=26 October 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20190708085435/http://xtf.lib.virginia.edu/xtf/view?docId=StudiesInBiblio%2FuvaBook%2Ftei%2Fsibv049.xml%3Bchunk.id%3Dvol049.06%3Btoc.depth%3D1%3Btoc.id%3Dvol049.06%3Bbrand%3Ddefault | archivedate=8 July 2019 | url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last=Jackson | first=MacDonald P. | authorlink=MacDonald P. Jackson | title=Shakespeare's Brothers and Peele's Brethren ''Titus Andronicus'' again | journal=[[Notes and Queries]] | volume=44 | issue=4 | date=November 1997 | pages=494–495 | url=http://nq.oxfordjournals.org/content/44/4/494.full.pdf+html | accessdate=16 July 2014 | doi=10.1093/notesj/44.4.494}} {{subscription required}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last=Vickers | first=Brian | authorlink=Brian Vickers | title=Shakespeare, Co-Author: A Historical Study of Five Collaborative Plays | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2002 | pages=148–243 | isbn=978-0-19-926916-7}}</ref> :'''''Evidence''''': E.A.J. Honigmann dates the play 1586, arguing it to be Shakespeare's first piece, written several years prior to his arrival in London.<ref>{{cite book | last=Honigmann | first=E.A.J. | authorlink=E. A. J. Honigmann |title=Shakespeare: The 'Lost Years' | location=Manchester | publisher=Manchester University Press | year=1998 | origyear=1985 | edition=2nd | pages=59–76 | isbn=978-0-7190-5425-9}}</ref> In his 1994 edition of the play for the New Cambridge Shakespeare, Alan Hughes makes a similar argument, suggesting a date of 1588.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Hughes | editor-first=Alan | title=Titus Andronicus | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=2006 | edition=Revised | origyear=1994 | page=6 | isbn=978-0-521-67382-2}}</ref> Most scholars, however, tend to favour a post-1590 date, although there is by no means a consensus amongst them as to what that date may be. In his introduction to the 2001 edition of the play for the New Penguin Shakespeare (edited by Sonia Massai), Jacques Berthoud argues for a date of 1591;<ref>{{cite book | last=Berthoud | first=Jacques | chapter=Introduction | editor-last=Massai | editor-first=Sonia | title=Titus Andronicus | location=London | publisher=Penguin | year=2001 | series=The New Penguin Shakespeare | page=xxiv-xxvi | isbn=978-0-14-101966-6}}</ref> in his 1984 edition for the Oxford Shakespeare, Eugene M. Waith argues for a date of 1592;<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Waith | editor-first=Eugene M. | title=Titus Andronicus | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=1984 | pages=8–10 | isbn=978-0-19-953610-8}}</ref> in his 1995 edition for the Arden Shakespeare, Jonathan Bate argues for a date of 1593.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Bate | editor-first=Jonathan | editor-link=Jonathan Bate | title=Titus Andronicus | location=London | publisher=Routledge | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=1995 | pages=66–79 | isbn=978-1-903436-05-9}}</ref> What is known is that the play is unlikely to have been written later than June 1592, as that was when the London theatres were closed due to an outbreak of plague. Additionally, stylistic analysis has shown that ''Titus'' belongs to Shakespeare's pre-plague group of plays.<ref name="Taylor 113-115">{{cite book | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | chapter=The Canon and Chronology of Shakespeare's Plays | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | title=William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1997 | edition=Revised | origyear=1987 | pages=113–115 | isbn=978-0-393-31667-4}}</ref> If it is assumed that the ''Henry VI'' trilogy was complete by March 1592 at the latest, it would suggest ''Titus'' was composed either immediately afterwards, or perhaps simultaneously as he was completing them, suggesting a date of late 1591/early 1592.<ref name="Taylor 113-115" />
=== ''[[Richard III (play)|Richard III]]'' (1592–1593) === [[File:Richardthird.jpg|thumb|upright=0.70|1597 quarto of ''Richard III'']] :'''''First official record''''': version of the play entered into the Stationers' Register by [[Andrew Wise]] on 20 October 1597 as "The tragedie of kinge Richard the Third w {{sup|th}} the death of the duke of Clarence." :'''''First published''''': version of the play published in quarto in December 1597 as ''The tragedy of King Richard the third. Containing, his treacherous plots against his brother Clarence: the pittiefull murther of his innocent nephewes: his tyrannicall usurpation: with the whole course of his detested life, and most deserved death'' (printed by Valentine Simmes for Andrew Wise). This text was republished in 1598 (by Thomas Creede for Wise), 1603 (again by Creede for Wise), 1605 (by Creede for Matthew Lawe), 1612 (again by Creede for Lawe) and 1622 (by [[Thomas Purfoot]] for Lawe). The ''Folio'' text appears under the title ''The Tragedy of Richard the Third, with the Landing of Earle Richmond, and the Battell at Bosworth Field''. :'''''Additional information (publication)''''': because the 1597 quarto is of such good quality, without the obvious errors common to the 'original' bad quartos, as designated by [[Alfred W. Pollard]] (the 1597 ''Romeo and Juliet'', the 1602 ''[[The Merry Wives of Windsor]]'', the 1600 ''[[Henry V (play)|Henry V]]'' and the 1603 ''[[Hamlet]]''<ref name="Pollard">{{cite book | last=Pollard | first=Alfred W. | authorlink=Alfred W. Pollard | title=Shakespeare Folios And Quartos | location=London | publisher=Methuen | year=1909 | isbn=978-1-57898-300-1}}</ref>), scholars are undecided as to the exact relationship between the quarto and the 1623 folio texts. If Q1 is a bad quarto, it is an uncommonly "good" bad quarto. It is thought that F1 was set from Q3 (the 1605 text), Q6 (the 1622 text) and the author's [[foul papers]],<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Jowett | editor-first=John | editor-link=John Jowett | title=The Tragedy of King Richard III | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2000 | page=[https://archive.org/details/tragedyofkingric0000shak_p5i3/page/118 118] | isbn=978-0-19-953588-0 | url=https://archive.org/details/tragedyofkingric0000shak_p5i3/page/118 }}</ref> and, as a result, Q1 and F1 differ from one another substantially. Most significantly, F1 contains roughly 230 lines not in Q1, Q1 contains roughly 40 lines not in F1, there are over 2000 textual differences, some scenes are arranged differently (including the order of the entry of the ghosts in 5.4), and Q1 has fewer characters than F1.<ref>{{cite book | last=Chambers | first=E.K. | authorlink=E. K. Chambers | title=William Shakespeare: A Study of Facts and Problems, Vol. I | location=Oxford | publisher=Clarendon | year=1930 | page=[https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp/page/n336 297] | url=https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | isbn=978-0-19-811773-5 | accessdate=26 October 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150909142016/https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | archivedate=9 September 2015 | url-status=dead }}</ref> There are two main theories: the quarto is a reported text, reconstructed from memory based on a performance of the play;<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Davison | editor-first=Peter | title=The First Quarto of King Richard III | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare: The Early Quartos | year=1998 | pages=12–26; 49–50 | isbn=978-0-521-04207-9}}</ref> the quarto is a performance text, a refined version of the longer folio text written by Shakespeare himself after the play had been staged.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Jowett | editor-first=John | editor-link=John Jowett | title=The Tragedy of King Richard III | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2000 | pages=[https://archive.org/details/tragedyofkingric0000shak_p5i3/page/110 110–127] | isbn=978-0-19-953588-0 | url=https://archive.org/details/tragedyofkingric0000shak_p5i3/page/110 }}</ref> No real consensus has been reached on this issue.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Lull | editor-first=Janice | title=King Richard III | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=2009 | origyear=1999 | edition=Revised | pages=219–230 | isbn=978-0-521-73556-8}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Siemon | editor-first=James R. | title=Richard III | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2009 | pages=417–460 | isbn=978-1-903436-89-9}}</ref> :'''''First recorded performance''''': the play was performed extensively in Shakespeare's lifetime, and evidence would seem to suggest it was one of his most popular plays; it is mentioned in ''Palladis Tamia'' in 1598 (as "''Richard the'' 3."), and by the time of the ''First Folio'' in 1623, had been published in quarto six times, and referenced by multiple writers of the day. Regarding specific performances however, there is little solid evidence. In 1602, [[John Manningham]] mentions seeing [[Richard Burbage]] playing the role of Richard, probably at the [[Globe Theatre|Globe]], where his performance so impressed a female member of the audience that she asked him to visit her later that night in the guise of [[Richard III of England|Richard]].<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Dover Wilson | editor-first=John | editor-link=J. Dover Wilson | title=Richard III | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The Dover Wilson Shakespeare | year=1961 | edition=2nd | origyear=1954 | page=xlvii | isbn=978-0-521-09496-2}}</ref> The earliest definite performance was at [[St James's Palace]] on 16 or 17 November 1633 by the [[King's Men (playing company)|King's Men]].<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Jowett | editor-first=John | editor-link=John Jowett | title=The Tragedy of King Richard III | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2000 | page=[https://archive.org/details/tragedyofkingric0000shak_p5i3/page/81 81] | isbn=978-0-19-953588-0 | url=https://archive.org/details/tragedyofkingric0000shak_p5i3/page/81 }}</ref> :'''''Evidence''''': it is known that ''Richard III'' was definitely a sequel to ''True Tragedy'', which was on stage by 23 June 1592, hence ''Richard III'' must have been written roughly around the same period.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Lull | editor-first=Janice | title=King Richard III | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=2009 | origyear=1999 | edition=Revised | pages=4–5 | isbn=978-0-521-73556-8}}</ref> A common argument regarding Shakespeare's chronology at this point in his career is that ''Richard III'' is a significantly better play than any of the ''Henry VI'' plays, with a much tighter structure, a more mature manner and a greater degree of stylistic control. This dramatic improvement in his writing is attributed to his absorbing the lessons of [[Senecan tragedy]] when composing ''Titus'', which he was then able to incorporate into ''Richard''.<ref>{{cite book | last=Mincoff | first=Marco | authorlink=Marco Mincoff | title=Shakespeare: The First Steps | location=Sofia | publisher=Bulgarian Academy of Sciences | year=1976 | pages=110–137}}</ref> Additionally, in his 2000 edition of the play for the Oxford Shakespeare, John Jowett argues that the play may originally have been written for [[Lord Strange's Men]], but Shakespeare added some new material after it had passed to [[Pembroke's Men]], a company which formed in mid-1592 and disbanded in September 1593. The patron of Strange's Men was [[Ferdinando Stanley, 5th Earl of Derby]], a direct descent of [[Thomas Stanley, 1st Earl of Derby]], a major character in the play. However Shakespeare altered much of his source material (Sir [[Thomas More]]'s ''History of King Richard III'') regarding this character, presenting him as far more heroic and honourable than does More. For example, Shakespeare has Thomas lead a battalion against Richard at the [[Battle of Bosworth Field]], when it was in fact his brother [[William Stanley (Battle of Bosworth)|William]] who led them. This suggests Shakespeare was writing with Ferdinando in mind, knowingly praising the ancestor of the company's patron. However, the play also takes the time to praise the ancestors of the patron of Pembroke's Men, [[Henry Herbert, 2nd Earl of Pembroke]]. Prior to the Battle of Bosworth, a list of names of lords who have joined [[Henry VII of England|Richmond]]'s cause is read aloud, two of whom are "Sir Walter Herbert, a renown'd soldier" (4.5.9) and "redoubted [[William Herbert, 2nd Earl of Pembroke|Pembroke]]" (4.5.11). This passage is completely extraneous to the rest of the plot, is almost always cut in performance and has been argued to be an addition to the original composition. Pembroke is later mentioned by Richmond, who asks for him to be sent to his tent to consult on the eve of battle (5.4.5-8), a request never mentioned again. Additionally, in Q1, Richmond is flanked by "three lords" in 5.2, but in F1, the lords are all named, one of whom is the previously mentioned Walter Herbert. Both the request for Pembroke, which is subsequently forgotten, and the change of the anonymous lord to a specific historical individual suggest addition after initial composition. Jowett argues that coupled with the narratively vital praise of Stanley's ancestor, the less integrated references to Herbert and Pembroke create something of a hypothetical internal chronology of composition in which Shakespeare initially writes the play for Strange's Men, but, perhaps due to the closing of the theatres in June 1592, the play passes to Pembroke's Men for a regional tour, at which point he adds the lines praising the ancestors of the new company in whose hands the play has now found itself.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Jowett | editor-first=John | editor-link=John Jowett | title=The Tragedy of King Richard III | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2000 | pages=[https://archive.org/details/tragedyofkingric0000shak_p5i3/page/5 5–7] | isbn=978-0-19-953588-0 | url=https://archive.org/details/tragedyofkingric0000shak_p5i3/page/5 }}</ref>
=== ''[[Edward III (play)|Edward III]]'' (1592–1593) === [[File:Edward the third title page.jpg|thumb|upright=0.70|1596 quarto of ''Edward III'']] :'''''First official record''''': entered into the Stationers' Register by Cuthbert Burby on 1 December 1595 as "a booke intituled Edward the Third and the blacke prince their warres w{{sup|th}} kinge Iohn of Fraunce." :'''''First published''''': published in quarto in 1596 as ''The Raigne Of King Edvvard the third'' (printed anonymously for Burby). This text was republished in 1599 (printed by Simon Stafford for Burby). :'''''First recorded performance''''': although it is known from the 1596 quarto title page that the play had been performed in London during the 1590s, the earliest recorded performance was not until 6 March 1911 at the [[Haymarket Theatre|Little Theatre]], directed by [[Gertrude Kingston]] and [[William Poel]]. However, this production presented only the first half of the play (dealing with the [[Edward III of England|Edward]]'s infatuation with the [[Catherine Montagu, Countess of Salisbury|Countess of Salisbury]]). Performed under the title, ''The King and the Countess'', it was presented in a single matinée performance with the anonymous sixteenth century [[liturgical drama]], ''[[Jacob]] and [[Esau]]''.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Melchiori | editor-first=Giorgio | editor-link=Giorgio Melchiori | title=King Edward III | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=1998 | page=46 | isbn=978-0-521-59673-2}}</ref> The first known performance of the complete text took place in June 1986 at the Globe Playhouse in Los Angeles, directed by Dick Dotterer, as part of the [[R. Thad Taylor|Shakespeare Society of America]]'s presentation of the entire 'canon' of [[Shakespeare Apocrypha]].<ref name="Melchiori 48">{{cite book | editor-last=Melchiori | editor-first=Giorgio | editor-link=Giorgio Melchiori | title=King Edward III | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=1998 | page=48 | isbn=978-0-521-59673-2}}</ref> The first known production of the play in the United Kingdom was in July 1987, at the [[Theatr Clwyd]], directed by [[Toby Robertson]].<ref name="Melchiori 48" /> :'''''Additional information (attribution)''''': first attributed to Shakespeare by the booksellers Richard Rogers and William Ley in 1656, Shakespeare's possible authorship of the play was first investigated by [[Edward Capell]] in 1760. Although the question of authorship remains unresolved, many scholars do now agree that Shakespeare was involved in some way with writing the play, and that it deserves a place in the Shakespearean canon. Specifically, the argument has been made that if ''1 Henry VI'' can be attributed to Shakespeare so too can ''Edward III'', as some scholars argue that Shakespeare only wrote about 20% of ''1 Henry VI'',<ref name="Taylor 1H6" /> whereas estimates for ''Edward III'' tend to range from 40%<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/6302847/William-Shakespeare-wrote-anonymously-published-play-expert-claims.html | title=William Shakespeare wrote anonymously published play, expert claims | newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] | date=12 October 2009 | accessdate=30 July 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903193039/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/6302847/William-Shakespeare-wrote-anonymously-published-play-expert-claims.html | archivedate=3 September 2014 | url-status=dead }}</ref> to all of it.<ref>{{cite book | last=Sams | first=Eric | authorlink=Eric Sams | title=Shakespeare's Edward III : An Early Play Restored to the Canon | location=New Haven, CT | publisher=Yale University Press | year=1996 | isbn=978-0-300-06626-5 | url-access=registration | url=https://archive.org/details/shakespearesedwa0000sams }}</ref> The play was included in the 2nd edition of the ''Riverside Shakespeare'' in 1996. In 1998, [[Giorgio Melchiori]] edited the first stand-alone scholarly edition of the play, for the New Cambridge Shakespeare. The play was also included in the 2nd edition of ''The Oxford Shakespeare: The Complete Works'' in 2005, edited by William Montgomery, and in the 2nd edition of the ''Norton Shakespeare'' in 2008. The Arden Shakespeare published an edition of the play in 2017, edited by Richard Proudfoot and Nicola Bennett. :'''''Evidence''''': ''Edward III'' has been assigned many different possible dates of composition by a number of scholars. For example, Karl P. Wentersdorf favours a date of 1589–1590.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Wentersdorf | first=Karl P. | title=The Date of ''Edward III'' | journal=[[Shakespeare Quarterly]] | volume=16 | issue=2 | date=Spring 1965 | pages=227–231 | jstor=2868273 | doi=10.2307/2868273}} {{subscription required}}</ref> [[MacDonald P. Jackson]] argues for 1590–1591.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Jackson|first=Macdonald P.|authorlink=MacDonald P. Jackson|date=September 1965|title=''Edward III'', Shakespeare and Pembroke's Men|url=|journal=[[Notes and Queries]]|volume=12|issue=9|pages=329–331|doi=10.1093/nq/12-9-329|via=[[Oxford Journals]]}} {{subscription required}}</ref> Roger Prior argues for a date of 1594.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Prior|first=Roger|date=June 1990|title=The Date of ''Edward III''|journal=[[Notes and Queries]]|volume=37|issue=2|pages=178–180|doi=10.1093/nq/37-2-178|via=[[Oxford Journals]]}} {{subscription required}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last=Prior | first=Roger | title=Was ''The Raigne of King Edward III'' a compliment to Lord Hundson | journal=Connotations | volume=3 | issue=3 | year=1993 | pages=242–264 | url=http://www.connotations.de/pdf/articles/prior00303.pdf | accessdate=13 August 2014 | url-status=dead | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903093745/http://www.connotations.de/pdf/articles/prior00303.pdf | archivedate=3 September 2014 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Obviously, the play was written by December 1595. A ''terminus post quem'' of 1590 can be fixed by Shakespeare's use of several post-1590 accounts of the defeat of the [[Spanish Armada]] in 1588.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Melchiori | editor-first=Giorgio | editor-link=Giorgio Melchiori | title=King Edward III | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=1998 | pages=4–5 | isbn=978-0-521-59673-2}}</ref> According to the title page of the 1596 quarto, the play had been performed recently in London, but no company information is provided. However, both MacDonald P. Jackson and Richard Proudfoot have argued that ''Edward III'' must have been part of the repertory of Pembroke's Men.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Proudfoot | first=Richard | title=''The reign of King Edward the Third'' (1596) and Shakespeare | journal=[[Proceedings of the British Academy]] | volume=71 |year=1985 | pages=169–185 | url=http://philpapers.org/rec/PROTRO-4 | accessdate=30 July 2014}} {{subscription required}}</ref> This would explain the absence of an acting company on the title page; the company that performed the play had disbanded during the closure of the theatres from June 1592 to March 1594 (Pembroke's Men disbanded in September 1593). Giorgio Melchiori believes the connection to Pembroke's Men can help date the play. All of the Shakespearean plays performed by Pembroke's Men are pre-plague; ''Taming of the Shrew'', ''The Contention'', ''True Tragedy'', ''Titus'' and ''Richard III''. These plays all feature relatively large casts, with an emphasis on platforms, at least two doors and an upper stage. ''Edward III'', however, needs only ten adult actors and one boy (the most cast intensive scene is 5.1). Battle scenes are also muted, especially when compared to ''True Tragedy'' or ''Richard III'', and the siege scene (4.2) requires no doors or upper stage. The conclusion reached by Melchiori regarding this evidence is that the writer(s) of the play were unsure where it was going to be staged, and therefore wrote it in such a way that it could be adequately staged by a small company performing on a basic stage. This would suggest it was written during the closure of the theatres, which places the date of composition sometime between mid-1592 and late 1593.<ref>{{cite book | last=Slater | first=Eliot | title=The Problem of The Reign of King Edward III: A Statistical Approach | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | year=1988 | pages=80–101 | isbn=978-0-521-12348-8}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Melchiori | editor-first=Giorgio | editor-link=Giorgio Melchiori | title=King Edward III | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=1998 | pages=6–9 | isbn=978-0-521-59673-2}}</ref>
=== ''[[The Comedy of Errors]]'' (1594) === :'''''First official record''''': Francis Meres' ''Palladis Tamia'' (1598), referred to as "''Errors''." :'''''First published''''': ''First Folio'' (1623). :'''''First recorded performance''''': probably on [[Massacre of the Innocents|Innocents Day]], 28 December 1594, at [[Gray's Inn]] (one of the four London [[Inns of Court]]). The only known evidence for this performance is the ''Gesta Grayorum'', a 1688 text printed for William Canning based on a manuscript apparently handed down from the 1590s, detailing the "[[Lord of Misrule|Prince of Purpoole]]" festival from December 1594 to February 1595.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Bland | editor-first=Desmond | title=Gesta Grayorum; or, The history of the high and mighty Prince Henry, Prince of Purpoole, Anno Domini 1594 | location=Liverpool | publisher=Liverpool University Press | year=1968 | isbn=978-1-240-78227-7}}</ref> According to the text, after a disastrous attempt to stage "some notable performance […] it was thought good not to offer any thing of Account, saving Dancing and Revelling with Gentlewomen; and after such Sports, a Comedy of Errors (like to ''[[Plautus]]'' his ''[[Menaechmi|Menaechmus]]'') was played by the Players. So that Night was begun, and continued to the end, in nothing but Confusion and Errors; whereupon, it was ever afterwards called, ''The Night of Errors''." As ''Comedy of Errors'' is indeed based on ''Menaechmus'', this is almost universally accepted as a reference to a performance of the play, probably by Shakespeare's own company, the newly formed Lord Chamberlain's Men.<ref>{{cite book | last=King | first=Ros | chapter=Introduction | editor-last=Dorsch | editor-first=T.S. | title=The Comedy of Errors | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=2004 | edition=Revised | origyear=1988 | pages=28–38 | isbn=978-0-521-53516-8}}</ref> The earliest known definite performance was at court on 28 December 1604.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Foakes | editor-first=R.A. | editor-link=R. A. Foakes | title=The Comedy of Errors | url=https://archive.org/details/comedyoferr00shak | url-access=registration | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Second Series | year=1962 | page=li | isbn=978-1-903436-01-1}}</ref> :'''''Evidence''''': traditionally, ''Errors'' has been dated quite early, and has often been seen as Shakespeare's first comedy, perhaps his first play.<ref>{{cite book | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | chapter=The Canon and Chronology of Shakespeare's Plays | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | title=William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1997 | edition=Revised | origyear=1987 | page=116 | isbn=978-0-393-31667-4}}</ref> However, stylistic and linguistic analysis (proportion of [[Verse (poetry)|verse]] to prose, amount of [[rhyme]], use of [[colloquialism]]-in-verse, and a rare word test) has placed it closer to the composition of ''[[Richard II (play)|Richard II]]'' and ''Romeo and Juliet'', both of which were written in 1594 or 1595.<ref name="Taylor 117">{{cite book | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | chapter=The Canon and Chronology of Shakespeare's Plays | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | title=William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1997 | edition=Revised | origyear=1987 | page=117 | isbn=978-0-393-31667-4}}</ref><ref name="Whitworth 1-10">{{cite book | editor-last=Whitworth | editor-first=Charles | title=The Comedy of Errors | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2003 | pages=1–10 | isbn=978-0-19-953614-6}}</ref> More specifically, the limited setting (it is one of only two Shakespeare plays to observe the [[Classical unities]]) and the brevity of the play (Shakespeare's shortest at 1777 lines), along with the great abundance of legal terminology, suggests the play may have been written specifically for the Gray's Inn performance. This would place its composition in the latter half of 1594.<ref name="Whitworth 1-10" /><ref>{{cite journal | last=Thomas | first=Sidney | title=The Date of ''The Comedy of Errors'' | journal=[[Shakespeare Quarterly]] | volume=7 | issue=4 | date=Autumn 1956 | pages=377–84 | jstor=2866357 | doi=10.2307/2866357}} {{subscription required}}</ref>
=== ''[[Love's Labour's Lost]]'' (1594–1595) === [[File:Loves labours tp.jpg|thumb|upright=0.70|1598 quarto of ''Love's Labour's Lost'']] :'''''First official record''''': the play was published in quarto in 1598, although the exact date is unknown, as it was not entered into the Stationers' Register at the time.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Hibbard | editor-first=G.R. | title=Love's Labour's Lost | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=1990 | page=67 | isbn=978-0-19-953681-8}}</ref> Also in 1598, [[Robert Tofte]] mentioned the play in his [[sonnet sequence]] ''Alba. The months minde of a melancholy lover''; "''Love's Labour Lost'', I once did see, a play/Y'cleped so, so called to my pain." The date of publication of ''Alba'' is unknown as it also was not entered into the Register. Additionally, the play is mentioned in Meres' ''Palladis Tamia'' (registered on 7 September, with a dedication dated 10 October). It is unknown exactly which one of these three constitutes the first official record of the play. :'''''First published''''': published in quarto in 1598 as ''A Pleasant Conceited Comedie called Loues labors lost'', the first known printing of a Shakespearean play to include his name on the title page (printed by William Wright for Cuthbert Burby).<ref>{{cite book | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | editor3-last=Jowett | editor3-first=John | editor3-link=John Jowett | editor4-last=Montgomery | editor4-first=William | title=The Oxford Shakespeare: The Complete Works | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2005 | edition=2nd | origyear=1986 | page=[https://archive.org/details/completeworks0000shak_f0m2/page/307 307] | isbn=978-0-19-926718-7 | url=https://archive.org/details/completeworks0000shak_f0m2/page/307 }}</ref> However, due to the note "Newly corrected and augmented," it is known that a previous publication must have existed, which has apparently been lost.<ref name="Taylor 117" /> :'''''First recorded performance''''': according to the quarto title page, the play was performed at court for [[Elizabeth I of England|Queen Elizabeth]] sometime over Christmas 1597, however, no further information is provided. The earliest definite performance took place sometime between 8 and 15 January 1605, for [[Anne of Denmark]], at either [[Henry Wriothesley, 3rd Earl of Southampton]] or [[Robert Cecil, 1st Earl of Salisbury]]'s house.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Carroll | editor-first=William C. | title=Love's Labour's Lost | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=2009 | pages=37–38 | isbn=978-0-521-29431-7}}</ref> :'''''Evidence''''': obviously, the play was written by Christmas 1597, but narrowing the date further has proved difficult, with most efforts focusing upon stylistic evidence. Traditionally, it was seen as one of Shakespeare's earliest plays. For example, [[Charles Gildon]] wrote in 1710; "since it is one of the worst of ''Shakespeare''{{'}}s Plays, nay I think I may say the very worst, I cannot but think that it is his first."<ref>Quoted in {{cite book | editor-last=Vickers | editor-first=Brian | editor-link=Brian Vickers (literary scholar) | title=William Shakespeare: The Critical Heritage Volume II, 1693–1733 | location=Oxford | publisher=Routledge | year=1974 | page=242 | isbn=978-0-415-48727-6}}</ref> For much of the eighteenth century, it tended to be dated to 1590, until Edmond Malone's newly constructed chronology in 1778, which dated it 1594.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Hibbard | editor-first=G.R. | title=Love's Labour's Lost | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=1990 | page=43 | isbn=978-0-19-953681-8}}</ref> In his 1930 chronology, E.K. Chambers found the play to be slightly more sophisticated than Malone had allowed for, and dated it 1595.<ref>{{cite book | last=Chambers | first=E.K. | authorlink=E. K. Chambers | title=William Shakespeare: A Study of Facts and Problems, Vol. I | location=Oxford | publisher=Clarendon | year=1930 | page=[https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp/page/n376 335] | url=https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | isbn=978-0-19-811773-5 | accessdate=26 October 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150909142016/https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | archivedate=9 September 2015 | url-status=dead }}</ref> Today most scholars tend to concur with a date of 1594–1595, and the play is often grouped with the 'lyrical plays'; ''Richard II'', ''Romeo and Juliet'' and ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]'', because of its prolific use of rhyming.
