Harvey also mentions the Earl of Essex as still alive, which would suggest he wrote the note prior to 25 February 1601, when Essex was executed. This would seem to narrow the date of composition to between September 1599 and February 1601. However, not all scholars accept that Harvey's note can be used for dating purposes, mainly due to the fact that it infers [[Thomas Watson (poet)|Thomas Watson]] (d.1592) and [[Edmund Spenser]] (d.1599) are both still alive, but also mentions [[John Owen (epigrammatist)|John Owen]]'s 1607 epigrams, making it impossible to ascertain exactly when the note was written.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Edwards | editor-first=Philip | title=Hamlet, Prince of Denmark | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=2003 | edition=Revised | origyear=1985 | page=5 | isbn=978-0-521-53252-5}}</ref> Stylistic evidence has also been cited, usually as illustrative of a date of composition of 1600 or 1601, with subsequent revisions up to, and possibly beyond, 1605. This dating, however, is far from universally accepted.<ref>{{cite book | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | chapter=The Canon and Chronology of Shakespeare's Plays | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | title=William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1997 | edition=Revised | origyear=1987 | pages=122–123 | isbn=978-0-393-31667-4}}</ref>
=== ''[[Twelfth Night]]'' (1601) === [[File:Wright–Molyneux Map.png|thumb|upright|[[Edward Wright (mathematician)|Edward Wright]]'s "A Chart of the World on [[Mercator projection|Mercator's Projection]]" ({{c.|1599}}), published in [[Richard Hakluyt]]'s 1600 edition of ''The Principal Navigations...'' and thought to have been referenced in the play.]] :'''''First official record''''': John Manningham's diary on 2 February 1602. :'''''First published''''': ''First Folio'' (1623), as ''Twelfe Night, Or what you will''. :'''''First recorded performance''''': John Manningham saw the play performed at the [[Middle Temple]] on [[Presentation of Jesus at the Temple|Candlemas]] (2 February) 1602. The acting company is unrecorded but is thought to have been the Lord Chamberlain's Men.<ref>{{cite book | editor1-last=Warren | editor1-first=Roger | editor2-last=Wells | editor2-first=Stanley | editor2-link=Stanley Wells | title=Twelfth Night, or What You Will | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=1994 | page=1n1 | isbn=978-0-19-953609-2}}</ref> :'''''Evidence''''': obviously the play was complete by February 1602. However, John Leslie Hotson believes it to have been written earlier, probably in late 1600. On the night of the [[Epiphany (holiday)|Feast of the Epiphany]] (6 January) 1601, it is known the Lord Chamberlain's Men performed a play at Whitehall for Queen Elizabeth and [[Virginio Orsini, Duke of Bracciano]]. However, although official records contain much information on the preparations for the play, the name of the play itself is never mentioned. An official description of the unnamed play dictates "that [it] shall be best furnished with rich apparel, have great variety and change of music and dances, and of a subject that may be most pleasing to her Majesty." Hotson believes the unnamed play of 1601 was ''Twelfth Night'', the title of which refers to the [[Twelfth Night (holiday)|Twelfth Night celebrations]] which bridge [[Christmas]] and the epiphany.<ref>{{cite book | last=Hotson | first=John Leslie | authorlink=John Leslie Hotson | title=The First Night of Twelfth Night | url=https://archive.org/details/firstnightoftwel0000hots | url-access=registration | location=London | publisher=Macmillan | year=1954 | isbn=978-0-8414-4779-0}}</ref> Most scholars disagree with Hotson on this point, however, believing the description could just as easily fit ''Much Ado'' as ''Twelfth Night'', and arguing that rather than Shakespeare naming the character of [[Orsino (Twelfth Night)|Orsino]] in honour of the Duke who would be watching the play, it is more likely he took the name after meeting the Duke prior to writing it.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Elam | editor-first=Keir | title=Twelfth Night | location=London | publisher=Cengage Learning | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2008 | pages=93–95 | isbn=978-1-903436-99-8}}</ref> Topical allusions serve only to fix 1599 as a ''terminus post quem''. [[Maria (Twelfth Night)|Maria]] makes reference to "the new map with the augmentation of the [[Indies]]" (3.2.74). This probably refers to [[Edward Wright (mathematician)|Edward Wright's]] "Chart of the World on [[Mercator projection|Mercator's Projection]]" in ''Certaine Errors in Navigation'', which was published in 1599,<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Story Donno | editor-first=Elizabeth | title=Twelfth Night, Or What You Will | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=2004 | edition=Revised | origyear=1985 | page=2n1 | isbn=978-0-521-53514-4}}</ref> or, less likely, to the second edition of [[Richard Hakluyt]]'s ''Principall Navigations, Voiages, and Discoveries of the English Nation'', published the same year.<ref>{{cite book | editor1-last=Warren | editor1-first=Roger | editor2-last=Wells | editor2-first=Stanley | editor2-link=Stanley Wells | title=Twelfth Night, or What You Will | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=1994 | page=1n2 | isbn=978-0-19-953609-2}}</ref> Two references to the "sophy" (2.5.170 and 3.4.269) refer to the Shah of Persia, who at the time was [[Abbas I of Persia|Abbas I]]. In 1599, Sir [[Anthony Shirley]] had returned from his travels in Persia, publishing his memoirs in 1600 to great success. This is further evidence of composition around the turn of the century.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Elam | editor-first=Keir | title=Twelfth Night | location=London | publisher=Cengage Learning | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2008 | pages=72–73 | isbn=978-1-903436-99-8}}</ref> However, [[Feste]]'s avoidance of the phrase "out of my element" because the word "element" is "overworn" (3.1.58) may be a reference to Thomas Dekker's ''Satiromastix'', which mocks the expression "out of my element" three times. ''Satiromastix'' was first acted in 1601, meaning, if one accepts the reference, 1601 must be the earliest possible date of composition.<ref name="Taylor 123">{{cite book | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | chapter=The Canon and Chronology of Shakespeare's Plays | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | title=William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1997 | edition=Revised | origyear=1987 | page=123 | isbn=978-0-393-31667-4}}</ref>
=== ''[[Troilus and Cressida]]'' (1600–1602) === [[File:William Shakespeare Troilus and Cressida title page.jpg|thumb|upright=0.70|1609 Q{{sup|b}} edition of ''Troilus and Cressida'']] :'''''First official record''''': entered into the Stationers' Register by James Roberts on 7 February 1603 as "the booke of Troilus and Cresseda<!--not a typo-->." :'''''First published''''': two different versions of the play were published in quarto in 1609. Q{{sup|a}} was published under the title ''The Historie of Troylus and Cresseida''. Q{{sup|b}} was published under the title ''The Famous Historie of Troylus and Cresseid. Excellently expressing the beginning of their loves, with the conceited wooing of Pandarus, Prince of Licia''. Both Q{{sup|b}} and Q{{sup|b}} were printed by George Eld for Richard Bonian and Henry Walley. Both versions of the play are identical apart from a different title page, and a note to the reader added to Q{{sup|b}}.<ref>{{cite book | last=Chambers | first=E.K. | authorlink=E. K. Chambers | title=William Shakespeare: A Study of Facts and Problems, Vol. I | location=Oxford | publisher=Clarendon | year=1930 | page=[https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp/page/n479 438] | url=https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | isbn=978-0-19-811773-5 | accessdate=26 October 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150909142016/https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | archivedate=9 September 2015 | url-status=dead }}</ref> The ''Folio'' text appears under the title ''The Tragedie of Troylus and Cressida''. :'''''Additional information (publication)''''': ''Troilus and Cressida'' has attained a degree of infamy amongst Shakespearean scholars due to the range of unanswered questions it raises. For example, it is unknown if the play was ever performed in Shakespeare's day. Q{{sup|a}} claims it had been acted by the King's Men at the Globe, but Q{{sup|b}} omits the reference to the King's Men and instead includes a note headed "A neuer writer, to an euer reader. Newes," which claims the play has never been staged. Apparently when Q{{sup|a}} was at press, the printers were informed that the play had not been performed and they therefore prepared a cancel title-page and the note to the reader, which claims it is a sign of the quality of the play that it has never been publicly staged ("never staled with the stage, never clapper-clewed with the palms of the vulgar"). It is unknown however, which text is correct – Q{{sup|a}} or Q{{sup|b}}. E.A.J. Honigmann has suggested that the play was written early in 1601, but never acted because of fears it may have been seen as a political allegory sympathetic to Robert Devereux, Earl of Essex.<ref>{{cite book | last=Honigmann | first=E.A.J. | authorlink=E. A. J. Honigmann | chapter=The Date and Revision of ''Troilus and Cressida'' | title=Textual Criticism and Literary Interpretation | editor-last=McGann | editor-first=Jerome J. | location=Chicago, IL | publisher=University of Chicago Press | year=1985 | pages=38–54 | isbn=978-0-226-55843-1}}</ref> :'''''First recorded performance''''': ''Troilus and Cressida'' has never been popular on stage, apparently even in Shakespeare's day. The earliest known performance is an adaptation by [[John Dryden]], called ''Troilus and Cressida, Or Truth Found Too Late'', which was staged at the [[Dorset Garden Theatre|Duke's Theatre]] in 1679.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Bevington | editor-first=David | editor-link=David Bevington | title=Troilus and Cressida | location=London | publisher=Thomas Nelson | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=1998 | page=90 | isbn=978-1-903436-69-1}}</ref> Although there is a record of a performance at [[Smock Alley Theatre|Smock Alley]] in Dublin some time prior to 1700, it is unknown if this production was of Shakespeare's original text, or Dryden's adaptation, which was being revived as late as 1734.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Bird | first=R.C. | title=Shakespeare on the Stage in Restoration Dublin | journal=[[Modern Language Association|PMLA]] | volume=56 | issue=2 | date=June 1941 | pages=369–378 | jstor=458956 | doi=10.2307/458956}} {{subscription required}}</ref> The earliest known production of the Shakespearean text was a heavily edited German language all-male production on 23 April 1898, at the [[Staatstheater am Gärtnerplatz]] in Munich.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Bevington | editor-first=David | editor-link=David Bevington | title=Troilus and Cressida | location=London | publisher=Thomas Nelson | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=1998 | page=92 | isbn=978-1-903436-69-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Shirley | editor-first=Francis A. | title=Troilus and Cressida | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=Shakespeare in Performance | year=2005 | page=1 | isbn=978-0-521-79684-2}}</ref> The first known production of the play in the United Kingdom was on 1 June 1907 at the [[Novelty Theatre|Great Queen Street Theatre]], directed by Charles Fry, using a mixture of amateur and professional actors in modern dress.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Muir | editor-first=Kenneth | editor-link=Kenneth Muir (scholar) | title=Troilus and Cressida | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=1982 | page=10 | isbn=978-0-19-953653-5}}</ref> :'''''Evidence''''': just as its early performance history is far from clear, so too is the date of the play's composition. 1598 can be fixed as a ''terminus post quem'', as Shakespeare definitely used [[George Chapman]]'s ''Seven Books of the Illiad of Homer'' as a source, which was entered into the Stationers' Register in April 1598. Some scholars have attempted to link the play to the War of the Theatres, particularly the reference to the "Prologue armed" (l.23), which may be an allusion to the prologue in Jonson's ''[[The Poetaster]]'' (1601), in which an obviously infuriated Jonson lashes out at his detractors. However, the prologue in ''Troilus'' was not included in either Q{{sup|a}} or Q{{sup|b}}, making it difficult to directly connect it to the squabbles between the playwrights.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Muir | editor-first=Kenneth | editor-link=Kenneth Muir (scholar) | title=Troilus and Cressida | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=1982 | pages=5–7 | isbn=978-0-19-953653-5}}</ref> Stylistic evidence is also inconclusive. A rare word test places it closest to ''Hamlet''. Ants Oras' pause test places it after ''Henry IV'' and before ''Othello'', but is unable to determine exactly where the play lies between the two. A colloquialism-in-verse test places it after ''Hamlet'' and before ''Twelfth Night''. Metrical analysis places it after ''Hamlet'' and ''Twelfth Night'' but before ''[[Measure for Measure]]'' and ''Othello''. This all suggests a date of composition of somewhere between 1600 and 1602, but the exact order in which ''Hamlet'', ''Twelfth Night'' and ''Troilus and Cressida'' were written seems impossible to determine.<ref name="Taylor 123" />
=== ''[[Sir Thomas More (play)|Sir Thomas More]]'' (1592–1595; Shakespeare's involvement, 1603–1604) === [[File:Sir Thomas More Hand D.jpg|thumb|upright=0.70|[[Manuscript|MS]] page of ''Sir Thomas More'', believed to be in [[Shakespeare's handwriting]].]] :'''''First official record''''': in the diary of [[Thomas Hearne (antiquarian)|Thomas Hearne]], on 17 January 1728. Hearne wrote "On the 12th of Oct. last M{{sup|r}} Murray<ref>Apparently an unknown John Murray.</ref> lent me a thin [[folio]] Paper [[Manuscript|MS]] done or sowed up in a [[Vellum]] Cover; on w{{sup|ch}} it is intitled, ''The Booke of Sir Thomas Moore''. This I have read over. It is wrote in the nature of a Play or Interlude, soon after his death, I believe. Tho' it appears from thence plainly, what a great, wise, good and charitable man Sir Thomas was, yet there is no particular of History in it, but what we know already. It is the original, being in many places strangely scored & in others so altered that 'tis hard to make some things out."<ref>Quoted in {{cite book | editor1-last=Gabrieli | editor1-first=Vittorio | editor2-last=Melchiori | editor2-first=Giorgio | editor2-link=Giorgio Melchiori | title=Sir Thomas More | location=Manchester | publisher=Manchester University Press | series=The Revels Plays | year=1990 | page=1 | isbn=978-0-7190-1632-5}}</ref> :'''''First published''''': 1844, edited by [[Alexander Dyce]] for the Shakespeare Society. Published under the name ''Sir Thomas More, A Play; now first printed''. :'''''Additional information (attribution)''''': that Shakespeare was involved in the composition of ''Sir Thomas More'' is now generally agreed upon.<ref>{{cite book | last =Woodhuysen | first=H.R. | chapter=Shakespeare's writing, from manuscript to print | title= The New Cambridge Companion to Shakespeare | edition=2nd | editor1-last=de Grazia | editor1-first=Margreta | editor2-last=Wells | editor2-first=Stanley | editor2-link=Stanley Wells | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | year=2010 | origyear=2001 | pages=31–44 | isbn=978-0-521-71393-1}}</ref> The first major scholarly edition of the play was published by [[Manchester University Press]] in 1990, under its "Revels Plays" banner, edited by Vittorio Gabrieli and Giorgio Melchiori. In 2011, the Arden Shakespeare also published a full scholarly edition, edited by John Jowett (who had also edited the play for the 2nd edition of the ''Oxford Shakespeare: Complete Works'' in 2005), The Revels Plays edition is subtitled "A play by Anthony Munday and Others. Revised by [[Henry Chettle]], Thomas Dekker, [[Thomas Heywood]] and William Shakespeare." The Arden edition includes the subheading "Original Text by Anthony Munday and Henry Chettle. Censored by [[Edmund Tylney|Edmund Tilney]]. Revisions co-ordinated by Hand C. Revised by Henry Chettle, Thomas Dekker, Thomas Heywood and William Shakespeare." The MS is a foul paper in the handwriting of Anthony Munday. Censorship notes are included throughout by Edmund Tilney, Master of the Revels. Revisions are by Chettle (Hand A), Dekker (Hand E), Heywood (Hand B) and, probably, Shakespeare (Hand D).<ref name="Oxford 813">{{cite book | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | editor3-last=Jowett | editor3-first=John | editor3-link=John Jowett | editor4-last=Montgomery | editor4-first=William | title=The Oxford Shakespeare: The Complete Works | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2005 | edition=2nd | origyear=1986 | page=[https://archive.org/details/completeworks0000shak_f0m2/page/813 813] | isbn=978-0-19-926718-7 | url=https://archive.org/details/completeworks0000shak_f0m2/page/813 }}</ref> Hand C is an unknown professional theatrical scribe who made several annotations on top of the alterations.<ref>{{cite book | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | chapter=The Canon and Chronology of Shakespeare's Plays | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | title=William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1997 | edition=Revised | origyear=1987 | page=124 | isbn=978-0-393-31667-4}}</ref> Shakespeare is thought to have worked on Scene 6, based upon handwriting and stylistic analysis. He may also have worked on Scene 8, although this is based purely on stylistic analysis, as Scene 8 exists only in a transcribed version by Hand C.<ref name="Oxford 813" /> Shakespeare's name was first linked to the play by [[Richard Simpson (writer)|Richard Simpson]] in 1871. One year later, [[James Spedding]] elaborated upon and rejected some of Simpson's claims, but ultimately concurred that Hand D was Shakespeare's.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Jowett | editor-first=John | editor-link=John Jowett | title=Sir Thomas More | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2011 | page=437 | isbn=978-1-904271-48-2}}</ref> In 1923, ''Shakespeare's Hand in the Play of Sir Thomas More'' saw a quintet of major scholars ([[Alfred W. Pollard]], [[W. W. Greg|W.W. Greg]], [[Edward Maunde Thompson|E. Maunde Thompson]], [[J. Dover Wilson]] and [[Raymond Wilson Chambers|R.W. Chambers]]) support the Shakespearean attribution. What is known for certain is that Hand D does bear a striking resemblance to the extant examples of [[Shakespeare's handwriting]], and if it is ''not'' his handwriting, it is not the handwriting of any contemporary playwright whose handwriting has survived. Thus, the vast majority of contemporary [[Palaeography|paleographers]] believe that Hand D is that of William Shakespeare.<ref>{{cite book | last=Metz | first=G. Harold | chapter=Voice and Credyt: The Scholars and ''Sir Thomas More'' | title=Shakespeare and Sir Thomas More: Essays on the Play and Its Shakespearean Interest | editor-last=Howard-Hill | editor-first=Trevor H. | editor-link=Trevor H. Howard-Hill | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | year=1989 | pages=[https://archive.org/details/shakespearesirth0000unse/page/11 11–44] | isbn=978-0-521-34658-0 | url=https://archive.org/details/shakespearesirth0000unse/page/11 }}</ref> :'''''First recorded performance''''': it is unknown if the play was ever performed during Shakespeare's day, although due to its censorship problems, it is highly unlikely. The earliest recorded performance occurred at [[Birkbeck, University of London]] in December 1922, where it was performed by the students and produced by members of the English department.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Jowett | editor-first=John | editor-link=John Jowett | title=Sir Thomas More | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2011 | page=108 | isbn=978-1-904271-48-2}}</ref> :'''''Evidence''''': the original play is traditionally believed to have been written sometime between 1592 and 1595 by Munday and Chettle. The early scenes of the play depict "[[Evil May Day]]", the name given to an anti-alien riot in London in May 1517. Anti-alien riots also occurred in 1593 and 1595, followed by the execution of the ringleaders. In the play, [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]] is depicted as being relatively merciful to the instigators of the riots, whereas in 1595, Queen Elizabeth showed no such leniency. The theory is that no playwright would have written a play which knowingly portrayed the current monarch in such a negative light when compared to a previous monarch, and as Munday was an occasional government spy, he would be even less likely to do so. This places the date of initial composition as prior to the 1595 executions but probably after the initial re-emergence of [[xenophobia]] in the autumn of 1592.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Blayney|first=Peter W.M.|date=April 1972|title=''The Booke of Sir Thomas Moore'' Re-Examined|url=|journal=Studies in Philology|volume=69|issue=2|pages=167–191|jstor=4173757}} {{subscription required}}</ref> Tilney's specific objections to the depiction of the riots and their aftermath suggest that he received the play when these issues were still considered sensitive.<ref>{{cite book | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | chapter=The Canon and Chronology of Shakespeare's Plays | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | title=William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1997 | edition=Revised | origyear=1987 | page=139 | isbn=978-0-393-31667-4}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last=Honigmann | first=E.A.J. | authorlink=E. A. J. Honigmann | title=Shakespeare, ''Sir Thomas More'' and Asylum Seekers | journal=Shakespeare Survey | volume=57 |year=2004 | pages=225–235 | url=http://universitypublishingonline.org/cambridge/shakespeare/chapter.jsf?bid=CBO9781139052764&cid=CBO9781139052764A021 | accessdate=17 August 2014 | doi=10.1017/CCOL0521841208.018| isbn=978-1-139-05276-4 }} {{subscription required}}</ref> Due to these censorship issues, the play was probably laid aside until after the death of Queen Elizabeth in 1603, when Tilney's objections would have carried less weight. The revisions were made at this point, although without the participation of Munday.<ref>{{cite book | editor1-last=Gabrieli | editor1-first=Vittorio | editor2-last=Melchiori | editor2-first=Giorgio | editor2-link=Giorgio Melchiori | title=Sir Thomas More | location=Manchester | publisher=Manchester University Press | series=The Revels Plays | year=1990 | pages=126–28 | isbn=978-0-7190-1632-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Jowett | editor-first=John | editor-link=John Jowett | title=Sir Thomas More | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2011 | pages=424–457 | isbn=978-1-904271-48-2}}</ref> Several aspects of the revision work support a date of 1603–1604. For example, the additions contain twenty-seven profanities forbidden by the [[Act to Restrain Abuses of Players]] (1606), making it highly unlikely they were added after this date. There are also three references in Chettle's revision work to the court (Sc.13.64<ref>Line references are to the 2011 Arden Shakespeare edition, edited by John Jowett, which does not divide the play into acts.</ref>), the King (Sc.13.78-80) and "Lord Spend-All's Stuart's" (Sc.13.110) which are probably references to James I, who came to power in 1603. There are also several parallels with Chettle's ''The Tragedy of Hoffman'' (written between 1602 and 1604).<ref>{{cite book | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | chapter=The Date and Auspices of the Additions to ''Sir Thomas More'' | title=Shakespeare and Sir Thomas More: Essays on the Play and Its Shakespearean Interest | editor-last=Howard-Hill | editor-first=Trevor H. | editor-link=Trevor H. Howard-Hill | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | year=1989 | pages=[https://archive.org/details/shakespearesirth0000unse/page/101 101–130] | isbn=978-0-521-34658-0 | url=https://archive.org/details/shakespearesirth0000unse/page/101 }}</ref> Stylistic analysis of Scene 6 also supports this date. MacDonald P. Jackson's examination of vocabulary and pauses-in-verse place the material between ''Twelfth Night'' and ''[[Macbeth]]''.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Jackson|first=MacDonald P.|authorlink=MacDonald P. Jackson|year=1978|title=Linguistic Evidence for the Date of Shakespeare's Addition to ''Sir Thomas More''|url=http://nq.oxfordjournals.org/content/CCXXIII/apr/154.extract|journal=[[Notes and Queries]]|volume=CCXXIII|issue=April|pages=154–156|accessdate=26 October 2014|via=}} {{subscription required}}</ref> A colloquialism-in-verse test places it after ''Twelfth Night'' and ''Troilus and Cressida''.<ref>{{cite book | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | chapter=The Canon and Chronology of Shakespeare's Plays | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | title=William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1997 | edition=Revised | origyear=1987 | page=125 | isbn=978-0-393-31667-4}}</ref>
=== ''[[Measure for Measure]]'' (1603–1604) === :'''''First official record''''': an entry in the Revels Account Book records a performance on 26 December 1604 of "Mesur for Mesur" by "Shaxberd." :'''''First published''''': ''First Folio'' (1623). :'''''First recorded performance''''': in the banqueting hall at Whitehall Palace on 26 December 1604, by the King's Men.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Lever | editor-first=J.W. | title=Measure for Measure | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Second Series | year=1965 | pages=[https://archive.org/details/measureformeasur00will/page/ xxxi] | isbn=978-1-903436-44-8 | url=https://archive.org/details/measureformeasur00will/page/ }}</ref> :'''''Evidence''''': obviously the play was written prior to December 1604. Internal evidence in the form of topical allusions suggest a date of 1603–1604. For example, 1.1.68-73 may allude to King James' dislike of crowds, which had become apparent in June 1603.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Bawcutt | editor-first=N.W. | title=Measure for Measure | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=1991 | page=4 | isbn=978-0-19-953584-2}}</ref> Another example is found at 4.3.8 ("the old women were all dead"). This is thought to refer to the plague sweeping London, which had become a significant problem in May 1603.<ref name="Taylor 126">{{cite book | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | chapter=The Canon and Chronology of Shakespeare's Plays | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | title=William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1997 | edition=Revised | origyear=1987 | page=126 | isbn=978-0-393-31667-4}}</ref> In 1.2, Lucio discusses with two gentlemen the possibility of an imminent peace, which would deprive soldiers of their occupation, followed immediately by a reference to a "sanctimonious pirate" (1.2.1-7). This may refer to King James' attempts in the summer of 1604 to negotiate a [[Treaty of London (1604)|peace treaty]] with Spain, which would greatly reduce the activities of pirates.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Bawcutt | editor-first=N.W. | title=Measure for Measure | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=1991 | page=2}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Gibbons | editor-first=Brian | title=Measure for Measure | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=2006 | edition=Revised | origyear=1991 | page=21 | isbn=978-0-521-67078-4}}</ref> If these allusions are accurate, it would place the date of composition as somewhere between summer 1603 and late 1604. This date is supported by stylistic analysis. Both a colloquialism-in-verse test and a metrical test place ''Measure'' after ''Twelfth Night'' and ''Troilus'', but before ''All's Well'', and a rare word test links it most closely to ''All's Well''.<ref name="Taylor 126" />
=== ''[[Othello]]'' (1603–1604) === [[File:Othello title page.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.70|1622 quarto of ''Othello''.]] :'''''First official record''''': an entry in the Revels Account Book records a performance on 1 November 1604 of "The Moor of Venis" by "Shaxberd." :'''''First published''''': version of the play published in quarto in 1622 as ''The Tragœdy of Othello, The Moore of Venice'' (printed by [[Nicholas Okes]] for [[Thomas Walkley]]). The ''Folio'' text appears under virtually same name; ''The Tragedie of Othello, the Moore of Venice''. :'''''Additional information (publication)''''': although the 1622 quarto text is not usually considered a bad quarto,<ref>{{cite book | last=Chambers | first=E.K. | authorlink=E. K. Chambers | title=William Shakespeare: A Study of Facts and Problems, Vol. I | location=Oxford | publisher=Clarendon | year=1930 | pages=[https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp/page/n500 459]–461 | url=https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | isbn=978-0-19-811773-5 | accessdate=26 October 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150909142016/https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | archivedate=9 September 2015 | url-status=dead }}</ref> it does differ significantly from the ''Folio'' text; F1 features roughly 160 lines not in Q1, and Q1 features twelve lines not in F1. The word ordering in some sentences is also different at several points throughout the play.<ref>{{cite book | editor1-last=Mowat | editor1-first=Barbara A. | editor2-last=Westine | editor2-first=Paul | title=The Tragedy of Othello, the Moor of Venice | location=New York, NY | publisher=Washington Square Press | series=Folger Shakespeare Library | year=1993 | page=[https://archive.org/details/othellofolgersha00will/page/ xlv] | isbn=978-0-7434-7755-0 | url=https://archive.org/details/othellofolgersha00will/page/ }}</ref> In his 2001 edition of Q1 for the New Cambridge Shakespeare: The Early Quartos series, Scott McMillin argues the quarto was created by a professional theatrical scribe listening to the actors performing the play, and in this sense, it represents as pure a performance text as it is possible to have.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=McMillin | editor-first=Scott | title=The First Quarto of Othello | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare: The Early Quartos | year=2001 | pages=31–44 | isbn=978-0-521-61594-5}}</ref> :'''''First recorded performance''''': in the banqueting hall at Whitehall Palace on 1 November 1604, by the King's Men.<ref name="Sanders 1">{{cite book | editor-last=Sanders | editor-first=Norman | title=Othello | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=2003 | edition=Revised | origyear=1984 | page=1 | isbn=978-0-521-53517-5}}</ref> :'''''Evidence''''': obviously the play was written by November 1604, and conventionally, it tends to be dated 1603–1604. An important element in this dating is Shakespeare's use of sources. For example, "burn like the mines of [[Sulfur|sulphur]]" (3.3.331), "one entire and perfect [[Topaz|chrysolite]]" (5.2.143), and "Drops tears as fast as the [[Commiphora myrrha|Arabian trees]]/Their medicinal gum (5.2.349-350) are all thought to allude to [[Philemon Holland]]'s translation of [[Pliny the Elder]]'s ''[[Natural History (Pliny)|Naturalus Historia]]'', published in 1601.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Honigmann | editor-first=E.A.J. | editor-link=E. A. J. Honigmann | title=Othello | location=London | publisher=Thomas Nelson | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=1997 | page=[https://archive.org/details/othelloardenshak00will/page/344 344] | isbn=978-1-903436-45-5 | url=https://archive.org/details/othelloardenshak00will/page/344 }}</ref> Additionally, Shakespeare probably took the information regarding the [[Ottoman–Venetian War (1570–73)#Ottoman conquest of Cyprus|Turkish invasion of Cyprus]] (found in 1.3, 2.1 and 2.2) from [[Richard Knolles]]' ''General History of the Turks'', which contains an [[epistle]] dated 30 September 1603. Specifically, he may have got the name Signor Angelo, mentioned in the sailor's report (1.3.16), from Angelus Sorianus, a Venetian commander discussed in Knolles. Also, the sailor's description of Turkish tactics, "The [[Ottoman Empire|Ottomites]], reverend and gracious,/Steering with due course toward the island of Rhodes,/Have there injoined with an after fleet" (1.3.34-36), may have come from Knolles' description of the Turkish fleets' actions prior to the siege of [[Nicosia]].<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Neill | editor-first=Michael | title=Othello, the Moor of Venice | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2006 | page=400 | isbn=978-0-19-953587-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last=Bate | first=Jonathan | authorlink=Jonathan Bate | title=Soul of the Age: The Life, Mind and World of William Shakespeare | location=London | publisher=Penguin | year=2008 | pages=298–299 | isbn=978-0-14-101586-6}}</ref> This suggests September 1603 as a likely ''terminus post quem''.<ref name="Sanders 1" /> A possible ''terminus ante quem'' could be March 1604, when Philip Henslowe paid Thomas Dekker and [[Thomas Middleton]] for Part 1 of ''[[The Honest Whore]]'', which contains the line "more savage than a barbarous Moor." Whilst not specific enough to be a definite reference to Shakespeare, it is known that ''Othello'' was immensely popular from its very inception, and such a reference would certainly have made sense to an audience at the time.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Sanders | editor-first=Norman | title=Othello | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=2003 | edition=Revised | origyear=1984 | page=2 | isbn=978-0-521-53517-5}}</ref> It has also been argued that the play may have been written with an eye to pleasing the new king, James I. James was interested in Turkish history, and had written a poem in 1591 about the [[Battle of Lepanto]]. The poem was republished upon his accession in 1603, and a play set amongst the events which ultimately led to that battle would have had a special interest for the king.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Jones | first=Emrys | title=''Othello'', "Lepanto" and the Cyprus Wars | journal=Shakespeare Survey | volume=21 |year=1968 | pages=11–20 | url=http://universitypublishingonline.org/cambridge/shakespeare/chapter.jsf?bid=CBO9781139053013&cid=CBO9781139053013A008 | accessdate=2 August 2014 | doi=10.1017/CCOL0521072859.005| isbn=978-1-139-05301-3 }} {{subscription required}}</ref> This would also support a date of 1603–1604. However, following H.C. Hart's 1928 edition of the play for the first series of the Arden Shakespeare, E.A.J. Honigmann dates the play mid-1601 to mid-1602, believing it to have influenced the bad quarto of ''Hamlet'' (in existence by July 1602). For example, he cites the substitution of the name "Montano" for "Reynaldo." Montano occurs in no other play except ''Othello'', and Honigmann believes the actor who worked on ''Hamlet'' Q1 played Reynaldo, but had played Montano in an earlier production of ''Othello'', and unconsciously mixed up the names.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Honigmann | first=E.A.J. | authorlink=E. A. J. Honigmann | title=The First Quarto of ''Hamlet'' and the Date of ''Othello'' | journal=[[The Review of English Studies]] | volume=44 | issue=174 | date=May 1993 | pages=211–219 | url=http://res.oxfordjournals.org/content/XLIV/174/211.full.pdf+html | accessdate=27 October 2014 | doi=10.1093/res/XLIV.174.211}} {{subscription required}}</ref> Additionally, MacDonald P. Jackson's pause analysis of the plays places ''Othello'' closest to ''Hamlet'', ''Troilus and Cressida'', ''Twelfth Night'' and ''Measure for Measure'', in that order. The "average date" for these four plays is 1602.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Jackson | first=MacDonald P. | authorlink=MacDonald P. Jackson | title=Pause Patterns in Shakespeare's Verse: Canon and Chronology | journal=Literary and Linguistic Computing | volume=17 | issue=1 | date=April 2002 | pages=37–46 | url=http://llc.oxfordjournals.org/content/17/1/37.extract# | accessdate=2 August 2014 | doi=10.1093/llc/17.1.37}} {{subscription required}}</ref> In his 2006 Oxford Shakespeare edition of the play, however, Michael Neill discusses Honigmann and Jackson's arguments, finding them suggestive, but not wholly persuasive, and ultimately settling for a "compromise date" of 1602–1603.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Neill | editor-first=Michael | title=Othello, the Moor of Venice | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2006 | pages=401–404 | isbn=978-0-19-953587-3}}</ref>
=== ''[[All's Well That Ends Well]]'' (1604–1605) === [[File:Samuel Taylor Coleridge by Washington Allston retouched.jpg|thumb|upright=0.70|''[[Samuel Taylor Coleridge]]'' by [[Washington Allston]] (1814). Coleridge's theory regarding the composition of ''All's Well'' was accepted for much of the nineteenth century.]] :'''''First official record''''': mentioned in the Stationers' Register entry for the ''First Folio'' on 8 November 1623. :'''''First published''''': ''First Folio'' (1623). :'''''First recorded performance''''': at [[Goodman's Fields Theatre|Goodman's Fields]] in 1741, billed as "written by Shakespeare and not acted since his time."<ref>{{cite book | last=Leggatt | first=Alexander | chapter=Introduction | editor-last=Fraser | editor-first=Russell | title=All's Well That Ends Well | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=2003 | edition=Revised | origyear=1985 | page=14 | isbn=978-0-521-53515-1}}</ref> :'''''Evidence''''': a notoriously difficult play to date, with estimates ranging from 1595 to 1607.<ref name="Hunter xix">{{cite book | editor-last=Hunter | editor-first=George K. | title=All's Well That Ends Well | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Second Series | year=1959 | page=xix | isbn=978-1-903436-23-3}}</ref> As an example of the disparity the play can cause in relation to its date, the 1997 revised edition of ''William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion'' from [[Oxford University Press]] dates the play 1604–1605, placing it between ''Othello'' and ''[[Timon of Athens]]''.<ref name="Taylor 126-127">{{cite book | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | chapter=The Canon and Chronology of Shakespeare's Plays | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | title=William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1997 | edition=Revised | origyear=1987 | pages=126–127 | isbn=978-0-393-31667-4}}</ref> However, the 2nd edition of the ''Oxford Shakespeare: Complete Works'' in 2005, compiled by the same editors as the ''Textual Companion'', date it 1606–1607, placing it between ''[[Antony and Cleopatra]]'' and ''[[Pericles, Prince of Tyre]]''.<ref>{{cite book | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | editor3-last=Jowett | editor3-first=John | editor3-link=John Jowett | editor4-last=Montgomery | editor4-first=William | title=The Oxford Shakespeare: The Complete Works | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2005 | edition=2nd | origyear=1986 | page=[https://archive.org/details/completeworks0000shak_f0m2/page/1031 1031] | isbn=978-0-19-926718-7 | url=https://archive.org/details/completeworks0000shak_f0m2/page/1031 }}</ref> Another example of scholarly mutability regarding the date of ''All's Well'' is Edmond Malone. In his 1778 chronology, Malone had accepted a theory originated by [[Thomas Percy (bishop of Dromore)|Thomas Percy]] and advanced by [[Richard Farmer]] that ''All's Well'' was ''Love's Labour's Won'', and so dated the play 1598. However, by the time of his death, Malone had changed his mind, and in the ''Third Variorum'' edition of 1821, edited by [[James Boswell (1778–1822)|James Boswell]] based on Malone's notes, he dated it 1606, based on a stylistic analysis of the anti-[[Puritan]] satire in 1.3, which he believed was written for King James' amusement.<ref name="Snyder 21">{{cite book | editor-last=Snyder | editor-first=Susan | title=All's Well That Ends Well | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=1993 | page=21 | isbn=978-0-19-953712-9}}</ref> Another scholar who has attempted to tackle the dating issues is [[Samuel Taylor Coleridge]]. In 1813, he formulated the theory that the play "as it has come down to us, was written at two different, and rather distinct periods of the poet's life."<ref name="Hunter xix" /> Further elaborated upon by John Payne Collier, this theory was widely accepted throughout the nineteenth century, with most scholars arguing for an initial period of composition in the mid-1590s and a second period in the mid-1600s.<ref name="Snyder 21" /> The basis of the argument was that although the play exhibited stylistic and thematic connections with ''Hamlet'' and ''Measure for Measure'', certain sections were seen as immature, and more akin to the type of material found in ''Two Gentlemen'', ''Taming of the Shrew'' or ''Comedy of Errors''. Often cited as immature were Helen's discussion about virginity in 1.1 and the [[Couplet|rhyming couplets]] in 2.1 and 2.2. Similarly, Parolles was seen by some as an early study for Falstaff, and the Clown was often seen as being similar to Launce in ''Two Gentlemen''; amusing, but not integrated into the plot particularly well.<ref name="Snyder 22">{{cite book | editor-last=Snyder | editor-first=Susan | title=All's Well That Ends Well | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=1993 | page=22 | isbn=978-0-19-953712-9}}</ref> Modern scholarship, however, which tends to see the play as more complex and serious than earlier scholars, has rejected the two-periods-of-composition theory.<ref name="Snyder 22" /><ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Hunter | editor-first=George K. | title=All's Well That Ends Well | location=London | publisher=Methuen | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Second Series | year=1959 | pages=xx–xv | isbn=978-1-903436-23-3}}</ref> Topical allusions in the play are sparse at best, with the only allusion recognised by most scholars being 1.3.94-95 ("wear the surplice of humility over the black gown of a big heart"), which is thought to be a reference to the enforcement of the [[surplice]] in 1604.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Snyder | editor-first=Susan | title=All's Well That Ends Well | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=1993 | page=23 | isbn=978-0-19-953712-9}}</ref> Stylistically, a rare word test links the play most closely with ''Measure for Measure''. A colloquialism-in-verse test places it after ''Measure'' and ''Othello'' but before ''Timon of Athens''. A metrical test places it after ''Measure'' and ''Othello'' but before ''Lear''.<ref name="Taylor 126-127" /> If one accepts the surplice reference, in tandem with the stylistic evidence, a date of 1604–1605 seems likely, but the exact order of composition of plays in this period remains open to speculation.<ref>{{cite book | last=Leggatt | first=Alexander | chapter=Introduction | editor-last=Fraser | editor-first=Russell | title=All's Well That Ends Well | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=2003 | edition=Revised | origyear=1985 | pages=10–11 | isbn=978-0-521-53515-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Snyder | editor-first=Susan | title=All's Well That Ends Well | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=1993 | page=24 | isbn=978-0-19-953712-9}}</ref>
=== ''[[King Lear]]'' (1605–1606) === [[File:Houghton STC 22292 - M. William Shak-speare, 1608.jpg|thumb|upright=0.70|1608 quarto of ''King Lear''.]] :'''''First official record''''': entered into the Stationers' Register by [[Nathaniel Butter]] and John Busby on 26 November 1607 as "A booke called. M{{sup|r}} William Shakespeare his historye of Kinge Lear." :'''''First published''''': version of the play published in quarto in 1608 as ''M. William Shakspeare: His True Chronicle Historie of the life and death of King Lear and his three Daughters. With the unfortunate life of Edgar, sonne and heire to the Earle of Gloster, and his sullen and assumed humor of Tom of Bedlam'' (printed by Nicholas Okes for Nathaniel Butter). This text was republished in 1619, as part of William Jaggard's "False Folio" (printed by Thomas Pavier). The 1623 ''Folio'' text appears under the title ''The Tragedie of King Lear''. :'''''Additional information (publication)''''': although the 1608 quarto text is not usually considered a bad quarto ''per se'',<ref>{{cite book | last=Chambers | first=E.K. | authorlink=E. K. Chambers | title=William Shakespeare: A Study of Facts and Problems, Vol. I | location=Oxford | publisher=Clarendon | year=1930 | pages=[https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp/page/n506 465]–466 | url=https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | isbn=978-0-19-811773-5 | accessdate=26 October 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150909142016/https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | archivedate=9 September 2015 | url-status=dead }}</ref> it does differ substantially from the ''Folio'' text; Q1 contains 285 lines not in F1, and F1 contains about 115 lines not in Q1. Additionally, over one thousand individual words are different between the two texts, each text has completely different punctuation, much of the verse in F1 is printed as prose in Q1, several speeches are given to different characters (including the final speech of the play – Albany in Q1, Edgar in F1) and each text features different scene divisions.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Halio | editor-first=Jay L. | title=The First Quarto of King Lear | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare: The Early Quartos | year=1994 | page=24 | isbn=978-0-521-61263-0}}</ref> The New Cambridge Shakespeare has published scholarly editions of both texts; F1 in 1992, and Q1 in 1994 as part of their Early Quartos series, both versions edited by Jay L. Halio. The 1999 Pelican Shakespeare edition of the play, edited by [[Stephen Orgel]] included both Q1 and F1, as well as the conflated text originally created by [[Alexander Pope]] in 1725. Similarly, the ''Oxford Shakespeare: Complete Works'' also included both versions of the play in their second edition of 2005, each edited by Gary Taylor. The Q1 text appears under the title ''The History of King Lear'', and is dated 1605–1606. The ''Folio'' text appears under the title ''The Tragedy of King Lear'' and is dated 1610. Taylor believes Q1 represents an early draft of the play, written prior to performance,<ref>{{cite book | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | editor3-last=Jowett | editor3-first=John | editor3-link=John Jowett | editor4-last=Montgomery | editor4-first=William | title=The Oxford Shakespeare: The Complete Works | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2005 | edition=2nd | origyear=1986 | page=[https://archive.org/details/completeworks0000shak_f0m2/page/909 909] | isbn=978-0-19-926718-7 | url=https://archive.org/details/completeworks0000shak_f0m2/page/909 }}</ref> and F1 represents a revision written four or five years later, after numerous performances. He feels the differences in the two texts represent a "more theatrical" version of the play, which streamlines the plot and improves the characterisation of Edgar, at the expense of Kent and Albany.<ref>{{cite book | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | editor3-last=Jowett | editor3-first=John | editor3-link=John Jowett | editor4-last=Montgomery | editor4-first=William | title=The Oxford Shakespeare: The Complete Works | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2005 | edition=2nd | origyear=1986 | page=[https://archive.org/details/completeworks0000shak_f0m2/page/1153 1153] | isbn=978-0-19-926718-7 | url=https://archive.org/details/completeworks0000shak_f0m2/page/1153 }}</ref> Although Halio disagrees with Taylor's assessment of F1 as "more theatrical," he reaches the same conclusion regarding the provenance of the text; Q1 was probably set from Shakespeare's foul papers, whilst F1 represents a performance text, probably altered by Shakespeare himself.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Halio | editor-first=Jay L. | title=The First Quarto of King Lear | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare: The Early Quartos | year=1994 | pages=24–26 | isbn=978-0-521-61263-0}}</ref> Most scholars today are in agreement with this theory.<ref>See, for example, the essays in {{cite book | editor1-last=Taylor | editor1-first=Gary | editor1-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | editor2-last=Warren | editor2-first=Michael | title=The Division of the Kingdoms: Shakespeare's Two Versions of King Lear | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=Oxford Shakespeare Studies | year=1983 | isbn=978-0-19-812950-9}}</ref> :'''''First recorded performance''''': according to the entry in the Stationers' Register in November 1607, the play was performed at Whitehall on 26 December 1606.<ref name="Halio 1">{{cite book | editor-last=Halio | editor-first=Jay L. | title=The Tragedy of King Lear | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=2005 | edition=Revised | origyear=1992 | page=1 | isbn=978-0-521-61263-0}}</ref> [[File:Popish Impostures 1603.jpg|thumb|upright=0.70|[[Samuel Harsnett]]'s ''A Declaration of egregious Popish Impostures'' (1603), one of Shakespeare's sources for ''Lear''.]] :'''''Evidence''''': although the existence of two distinct texts complicates the issue of dating the play, what is known for certain is that it must have been completed (in some form) by December 1606. The play could not have been written any earlier than March 1603, as determined by Shakespeare's use of [[Samuel Harsnett]]'s ''Declaration of Egregious Popish Impostures'', from which he took some of Tom O'Bedlam's dialogue, which was entered into the Stationers' Register on 16 March 1603.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Wells | editor-first=Stanley | editor-link=Stanley Wells | title=The History of King Lear | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2000 | page=10 | isbn=978-0-19-953582-8}}</ref> However, the ''terminus post quem'' can possibly be pushed forward to 1605. Gary Taylor believes that ''Lear'' was influenced by George Chapman, Ben Jonson and John Marston's ''[[Eastward Hoe|Eastward Ho]]'', written in early 1605, and [[George Wilkins]]' ''[[The Miseries of Enforced Marriage]]'', written no later than mid-1605.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | title=A New Source and an Old Date for ''King Lear'' | journal=[[The Review of English Studies]] | volume=33 | issue=132 | date=November 1982 | pages=396–413 | url=http://res.oxfordjournals.org/content/XXXIII/132/396.full.pdf+html | accessdate=27 October 2014 | doi=10.1093/res/XXXIII.132.396}} {{subscription required}}</ref> Furthermore, the line "these late eclipses in the sun and moon" (Sc.2.101<ref>Stanley Wells' 2000 edition of the play for the Oxford Shakespeare does not divide the play into acts.</ref>) could refer to the [[lunar eclipse]] of 17 September and the [[solar eclipse]] of 2 October 1605.<ref name="Halio 1" /><ref>{{cite book | last=Shaheen | first=Naseeb | authorlink=Naseeb Shaheen | title=Biblical References in Shakespeare's Plays | location=Cranbury, NJ | publisher=Associated University Presses | year=1999 | page=606 | isbn=978-1-61149-358-0}}</ref> Of vital importance in dating the play, however, is the 1605 publication of an older version of the story, the anonymous play ''[[King Leir|The true Chronicle History of King Leir and his three daughters, Gonorill, Ragan and Cordella]]''. The publication of ''Leir'' in 1605 is often taken as evidence that Shakespeare's ''Lear'' was on stage by 1605. ''Leir'' was entered into the Stationers' Register on 14 May 1594, but had already been staged, and is usually dated to ''c.''1590. There is no evidence it was ever published prior to 1605, and its sudden appearance in print over ten years after its composition could represent evidence of an attempt to capitalise on the success of Shakespeare's newly released play.<ref name="Halio 1-2">{{cite book | editor-last=Halio | editor-first=Jay L. | title=The Tragedy of King Lear | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=2005 | edition=Revised | origyear=1992 | pages=1–2 | isbn=978-0-521-61263-0}}</ref> On the other hand, in his 1997 edition of the play for the third series of the Arden Shakespeare, [[R. A. Foakes|R.A. Foakes]] argues the 1605 publication of ''Leir'' inspired Shakespeare to write his own version of the story. There is little doubt that Shakespeare used ''Leir'' as a source, and Foakes' believes that some of the parallels are too specific to represent Shakespeare's remembrance of a performance, rather he must have been working with a printed copy. Foakes also argues that the title page of Q1 specifically recalls the title page of the 1605 ''Leir'' to "alert" readers to the fact that Shakespeare's version is based on the older version, but is much improved. For example, this explains the reference to Edgar and Gloucester on the title page. These characters are not in ''Leir'', and their inclusion in the title of Q1 serves as an advertisement that Shakespeare's version of the story is more complex than ''Leir''. If Foakes is correct, it means Shakespeare could not have started writing ''Lear'' until May 1605.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Foakes | editor-first=R.A. | editor-link=R. A. Foakes | title=King Lear | location=London | publisher=Thomas Nelson | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=1997 | pages=[https://archive.org/details/kinglearardensha00will/page/89 89–100] | isbn=978-1-903436-59-2 | url=https://archive.org/details/kinglearardensha00will/page/89 }}</ref> In his 2000 edition of the play for the Oxford Shakespeare, however, Stanley Wells argues there are echoes of ''Leir'' in plays as chronologically wide-ranging as ''The Taming of the Shrew'', ''Richard II'', ''Much Ado About Nothing'' and ''Hamlet'', suggesting Shakespeare was very familiar with the play from at least the early 1590s.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Wells | editor-first=Stanley | editor-link=Stanley Wells | title=The History of King Lear | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2000 | page=12 | isbn=978-0-19-953582-8}}</ref> The publication of ''Leir'' in 1605 could also be connected to the case of Brian Annesley, a wealthy Kentishman, who may, or may not, have influenced Shakespeare in writing ''Lear''. In 1603, Annesley's eldest daughter, Grace, tried to have him declared a lunatic so she would be placed in charge of his estate. She seems to have been supported in this by her husband (Sir John Wildgose), her sister (Christian) and her brother-in-law (William Sandys). However, Annesley's youngest daughter, Cordell, wrote to Robert Cecil, Earl of Salisbury for help, and successfully blocked Grace's plan. Annesley died in July 1604, and most of his estate was left to Cordell. Whether or not Shakespeare knew about the case is unknown, but if he did, it provides more evidence for a date of composition in the period 1604–1606.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Foakes | editor-first=R.A. | editor-link=R. A. Foakes | title=King Lear | location=London | publisher=Thomas Nelson | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=1997 | page=[https://archive.org/details/kinglearardensha00will/page/92 92] | isbn=978-1-903436-59-2 | url=https://archive.org/details/kinglearardensha00will/page/92 }}</ref> Whatever the case regarding ''Leir'' and Annesley, however, Halio,<ref name="Halio 1-2" /> Foakes,<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Foakes | editor-first=R.A. | editor-link=R. A. Foakes | title=King Lear | location=London | publisher=Thomas Nelson | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=1997 | page=[https://archive.org/details/kinglearardensha00will/page/89 89] | isbn=978-1-903436-59-2 | url=https://archive.org/details/kinglearardensha00will/page/89 }}</ref> and Wells<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Wells | editor-first=Stanley | editor-link=Stanley Wells | title=The History of King Lear | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2000 | page=14 | isbn=978-0-19-953582-8}}</ref> all date the initial composition of the play to 1605–1606. In regards to the revision of the text, stylistic analysis tends to view Q1 and F1 as two distinct texts, and in this sense, a rare word test, pause test and metrical test of Q1 all place it between ''Othello'' and ''Macbeth'', and either immediately before or immediately after ''Timon of Athens''.<ref>{{cite book | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | chapter=The Canon and Chronology of Shakespeare's Plays | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | title=William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1997 | edition=Revised | origyear=1987 | page=128 | isbn=978-0-393-31667-4}}</ref> A rare word test of the passages unique to F1, however, place it closest to ''[[The Winter's Tale]]'', ''[[Cymbeline]]'', ''[[The Tempest]]'' and ''Henry VIII''.<ref name="Taylor 131">{{cite book | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | chapter=The Canon and Chronology of Shakespeare's Plays | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | title=William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1997 | edition=Revised | origyear=1987 | page=131 | isbn=978-0-393-31667-4}}</ref>
=== ''[[Timon of Athens]]'' (1605–1606) === [[File:Thomas Middleton.jpg|thumb|upright=0.70|Thomas Middleton, who probably worked on ''Timon'' in some capacity.]] :'''''First official record''''': mentioned in the Stationers' Register entry for the ''First Folio'', on 8 November 1623. :'''''First published''''': ''First Folio'' (1623), as ''The Life of Tymon of Athens''. :'''''First recorded performance''''': there is no known evidence of a performance in Shakespeare's lifetime. The earliest known production of the play was in 1674, when [[Thomas Shadwell]] wrote an adaptation under the title ''[[The History of Timon of Athens the Man-hater|The History of Timon of Athens, The Man-hater]]''.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Jowett | editor-first=John | editor-link=John Jowett | title=The Life of Timon of Athens | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2004 | page=89 | isbn=978-0-19-953744-0}}</ref> Multiple other adaptations followed over the next century, by writers such as [[Thomas Hull (actor)|Thomas Hull]], [[James Love (poet)|James Love]] and [[Richard Cumberland (dramatist)|Richard Cumberland]].<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Dawson | editor-first=Anthony B. | editor2-last=Minton | editor2-first=Gretchen E. | title=Timon of Athens | location=London | publisher=Cengage Learning | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2008 | pages=109–116 | isbn=978-1-903436-97-4}}</ref> Although the earliest known performance of the straight Shakespearean text was at Smock Alley in Dublin in 1761, adaptations continued to dominate the stage until well into the twentieth century.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Jowett | editor-first=John | editor-link=John Jowett | title=The Life of Timon of Athens | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2004 | page=93 | isbn=978-0-19-953744-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Dawson | editor-first=Anthony B. | editor2-last=Minton | editor2-first=Gretchen E. | title=Timon of Athens | location=London | publisher=Cengage Learning | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2008 | page=112 | isbn=978-1-903436-97-4}}</ref> The earliest known production of a predominantly Shakespearean version of the play in the United Kingdom was at [[Sadler's Wells Theatre|Sadler's Wells]] in 1851. Adapted by [[Samuel Phelps]], the production cut all scenes involving the Fool, the return of the Poet and the Painter and much of the sexual material. He also changed the ending, having a solemn [[Alcibiades (character)|Alcibiades]] marching to [[Timon of Athens (person)|Timon's]] grave and reading the [[epitaph]] himself, a far less ambiguous ending than the original.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Jowett | editor-first=John | editor-link=John Jowett | title=The Life of Timon of Athens | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2004 | pages=116–117 | isbn=978-0-19-953744-0}}</ref> :'''''Additional information (attribution)''''': dating ''Timon of Athens'' is rendered more difficult because of the probable involvement of Thomas Middleton. The play contains several narrative inconsistencies uncharacteristic of Shakespeare, an unusually unsatisfying ''dénouement'', drastically different styles in different places and an unusually large number of long lines which don't [[Scansion|scan]].<ref>{{cite book | last=Chambers | first=E.K. | authorlink=E. K. Chambers | title=William Shakespeare: A Study of Facts and Problems, Vol. I | location=Oxford | publisher=Clarendon | year=1930 | pages=[https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp/page/n522 481]–482 | url=https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | isbn=978-0-19-811773-5 | accessdate=26 October 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150909142016/https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | archivedate=9 September 2015 | url-status=dead }}</ref> One theory is that the play as it appears in the ''First Folio'' is unfinished.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Ellis-Fermor | first=Una | title=''Timon of Athens'': An Unfinished Play | journal=[[The Review of English Studies]] | volume=18 | issue=71 | date=July 1942 | pages=270–283 | url=http://res.oxfordjournals.org/content/os-XVIII/71/270.full.pdf+html | accessdate=27 October 2014 | doi=10.1093/res/os-XVIII.71.270}} {{subscription required}}</ref> E.K. Chambers believes Shakespeare began the play, but abandoned it due to a mental breakdown, never returning to finish it.<ref>{{cite book | last=Chambers | first=E.K. | authorlink=E. K. Chambers | title=William Shakespeare: A Study of Facts and Problems, Vol. I | location=Oxford | publisher=Clarendon | year=1930 | pages=[https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp/page/n523 482]–483 | url=https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | isbn=978-0-19-811773-5 | accessdate=26 October 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150909142016/https://archive.org/details/williamshakespea017475mbp | archivedate=9 September 2015 | url-status=dead }}</ref> F.W. Brownlow believes the play to have been Shakespeare's last, and remained uncompleted at his death.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Brownlow | editor-first=F.W. | title=Two Shakespearean Sequences: Henry VI to Richard II, and Pericles to Timon of Athens | url=https://archive.org/details/twoshakespearean0000brow_s5b7 | url-access=registration | location=Pittsburgh, PA | publisher=University of Pittsburgh Press | year=1977 | isbn=978-0-8229-1127-2}}</ref> A more predominant theory, however, is one proposed by [[Charles Knight (publisher)|Charles Knight]] in 1838; the play was a collaboration between Shakespeare and at least one other dramatist. Today, many scholars believe that other dramatist was Thomas Middleton.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Dawson | editor-first=Anthony B. | editor2-last=Minton | editor2-first=Gretchen E. | title=Timon of Athens | location=London | publisher=Cengage Learning | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2008 | pages=1–10 | isbn=978-1-903436-97-4}}</ref> However, the exact nature of the collaboration is disputed. Did Middleton revise a piece begun by Shakespeare, did Shakespeare revise Middleton's work, or did they work together?<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Klein | editor-first=Karl | title=Timon of Athens | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=2001 | pages=[https://archive.org/details/timonofathens0000shak_v3p2/page/66 66–67] | isbn=978-0-521-29404-1 | url=https://archive.org/details/timonofathens0000shak_v3p2/page/66 }}</ref> John Jowett, editor of the play for both the ''Oxford Shakespeare: Complete Works'' and the individual Oxford Shakespeare edition, believes Middleton worked with Shakespeare in an understudy capacity and wrote scenes 2 (1.2 in editions which divide the play into acts), 5 (3.1), 6 (3.2), 7 (3.3), 8 (3.4), 9 (3.5), 10 (3.6) and the last eighty lines of 14 (4.3).<ref>{{cite book | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | editor3-last=Jowett | editor3-first=John | editor3-link=John Jowett | editor4-last=Montgomery | editor4-first=William | title=The Oxford Shakespeare: The Complete Works | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2005 | edition=2nd | origyear=1986 | page=[https://archive.org/details/completeworks0000shak_f0m2/page/943 943] | isbn=978-0-19-926718-7 | url=https://archive.org/details/completeworks0000shak_f0m2/page/943 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Jowett | editor-first=John | editor-link=John Jowett | title=The Life of Timon of Athens | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2004 | page=2 | isbn=978-0-19-953744-0}}</ref> :'''''Evidence''''': because there is no reference to ''Timon'' until 1623, attempts to date the play must rely on topical allusions and stylistic analysis. A possible ''terminus ante quem'' is 1608. In his 2004 edition for the Oxford Shakespeare, John Jowett argues the lack of act divisions in the ''Folio'' text is an important factor in determining a date. The King's Men only began to use act divisions in their scripts when they occupied the indoor Blackfriars Theatre in August 1608 as their winter playhouse. ''Timon'' is notoriously difficult to divide into acts, suggesting to Jowett that it was written at a time when act divisions were of no concern to the writer, hence it must have been written prior to August 1608.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Jowett | editor-first=John | editor-link=John Jowett | title=The Life of Timon of Athens | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2004 | page=4 | isbn=978-0-19-953744-0}}</ref> A ''terminus post quem'' may come from a possible topical allusion to the [[Gunpowder Plot]] of November 1605; "those that under hot ardent zeal would set whole realms on fire" (Sc.7.32-33<ref>John Jowett's 2004 edition of the play for the Oxford Shakespeare does not divide the play into acts. In editions which do divide the play, Oxford's Scene 7 is usually Act 3, Scene 3.</ref>). In the context of the play, the line is referring to religious zeal, but some scholars feel it is a subtle reference to the events of November.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Dawson | editor-first=Anthony B. | editor2-last=Minton | editor2-first=Gretchen E. | title=Timon of Athens | location=Boston, MA | publisher=Cengage Learning | series=The Arden Shakespeare, Third Series | year=2008 | pages=12–13 | isbn=978-1-903436-97-4}}</ref> The play may also have been influenced by a pamphlet published in June 1605, ''Two Unnatural and Bloody Murders'', which served as the primary source for Thomas Middleton's ''[[A Yorkshire Tragedy]]''.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Jowett | editor-first=John | editor-link=John Jowett | title=The Life of Timon of Athens | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2004 | page=6 | isbn=978-0-19-953744-0}}</ref> This would narrow the possible range of dates to sometime between November 1605 and August 1608. Narrowing the date further, however, must come wholly from stylistic analysis. A metrical test links the play most closely with ''Hamlet'', ''Troilus and Cressida'' and ''King Lear'', whilst a colloquialism-in-verse test places it after ''All's Well'' but before ''Macbeth''.<ref>{{cite book | last=Taylor | first=Gary | authorlink=Gary Taylor (scholar) | chapter=The Canon and Chronology of Shakespeare's Plays | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | title=William Shakespeare: A Textual Companion | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1997 | edition=Revised | origyear=1987 | pages=127–128 | isbn=978-0-393-31667-4}}</ref> Furthermore, MacDonald P. Jackson's rare word test found the conjectured Shakespearean parts of the text date to 1605–1606. However, if one were to analyse the conjectured non-Shakespearean sections as if they were by Shakespeare, the rare word test produces a date of 1594–1595, an obvious impossibility. Going further, Jackson found that if one examines the non-Shakespearean sections in the context of Middleton's career, a date of 1605–1606 also results.<ref>{{cite book | last=Jackson | first=MacDonald P. | authorlink=MacDonald P. Jackson | title=Studies in Attribution: Middleton and Shakespeare | location=Salzburg | publisher=Institut für Anglistik und Amerikanistik | year=1979 | page=155 | isbn=978-3-7052-0370-9}}</ref>
=== ''[[Macbeth]]'' (1606) === [[File:Portrait of Henry Garnett.jpg|thumb|upright=0.70|[[Henry Garnet]], executed for his involvement in the [[Gunpowder Plot]], and possibly referred to by the Porter in ''Macbeth''.]] :'''''First official record''''': in his [[Book of Plays|notes for a book]] on "Common Policy" (i.e. public morals), [[Simon Forman]] records seeing the play at the Globe on 20 April 1611. He actually dates the performance "1610, the 20th April, Saturday," but in 1610, 20 April was a Tuesday, and most scholars feel he accidentally wrote the wrong year.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Brooke | editor-first=Nicholas | title=The Tragedy of Macbeth | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2008 | page=234 | isbn=978-0-19-953583-5}}</ref> :'''''First published''''': ''First Folio'' (1623), as ''The Tragedie of Macbeth''. :'''''First recorded performance''''': possibly on 20 April 1611 at the Globe, recorded by Simon Forman. However, there is some doubt amongst scholars as to the veracity of Forman's account. Initially, the document itself was thought to be a forgery, as it was first brought to light by John Payne Collier amongst a group of documents many of which did prove to be inauthentic. Although J. Dover Wilson proved the document was genuine in 1947,<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Dover Wilson | first1=John | author1link=J. Dover Wilson | last2=Hunt | first2=R.W. | title=The Authenticity of Simon Forman's Bocke of Plaies | journal=[[The Review of English Studies]] | volume=23 | issue=91 | date=July 1947 | pages=193–200 | url=http://res.oxfordjournals.org/content/os-XXIII/91/193.full.pdf+html | accessdate=27 October 2014 | doi=10.1093/res/os-XXIII.91.193}}</ref> doubts remain as to the reliability of Forman's report. For example, he makes no mention of the apparitions, or of [[Hecate]], and he virtually ignores the conclusion of the play, which is strange considering he was taking notes for a book about morals. He also mentions seeing [[Macbeth (character)|Macbeth]] and [[Banquo]] on horseback riding through a wood, something highly unlikely on the Globe stage. Furthermore, he describes the [[Three Witches|Weïrd Sisters]] as "nymphs or fairies," an unusual way to describe the characters as they appear in the play. However, "nymphs" is how they are described in one of Shakespeare's sources for ''Macbeth'', ''[[Holinshed's Chronicles]]''. This suggests Forman may have conflated witnessing a performance with reading the source material.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Brooke | editor-first=Nicholas | title=The Tragedy of Macbeth | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2008 | pages=234–235 | isbn=978-0-19-953583-5}}</ref> If Forman's account is not accepted as genuine, the first recorded performance was on 5 November 1664, as recorded by Samuel Pepys.<ref name="Brooke 37">{{cite book | editor-last=Brooke | editor-first=Nicholas | title=The Tragedy of Macbeth | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | series=The Oxford Shakespeare | year=2008 | pages=37 | isbn=978-0-19-953583-5}}</ref> :'''''Additional information (revision)''''': because it is theorised by some scholars that the ''Folio'' text of ''Macbeth'' shows signs of revision, dating the play can be difficult. ''Macbeth'' is extremely short for a Shakespearean tragedy, and it is thought that F1 may have been set from a [[prompt book]] that had been shortened for performance, rather than from Shakespeare's own foul papers. First suggested by W.G. Clarke and W.A. Wright in their 1869 edition of the play for [[Oxford University Press|Clarendon Press]], the most likely person to have carried out the revision is Thomas Middleton.<ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Braunmuller | editor-first=A.R. | title=Macbeth | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | series=The New Cambridge Shakespeare | year=2008 | origyear=1997 | edition=Revised | pages=261–279 | isbn=978-0-521-86240-0}}</ref> The play is listed in the ''Oxford Shakespeare: Complete Works'' as "''The Tragedy of Macbeth'' by William Shakespeare, Adapted by Thomas Middleton,"<ref name="Oxford 969">{{cite book | editor1-last=Wells | editor1-first=Stanley | editor1-link=Stanley Wells | editor2-last=Taylor | editor2-first=Gary | editor2-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | editor3-last=Jowett | editor3-first=John | editor3-link=John Jowett | editor4-last=Montgomery | editor4-first=William | title=The Oxford Shakespeare: The Complete Works | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2005 | edition=2nd | origyear=1986 | page=[https://archive.org/details/completeworks0000shak_f0m2/page/969 969] | isbn=978-0-19-926718-7 | url=https://archive.org/details/completeworks0000shak_f0m2/page/969 }}</ref> and its date is recorded as "1606; adapted 1616." Middleton is conjectured to have written 3.5 and much of 4.1; the only scenes which feature Hecate. The nature of these scenes suggest revision as opposed to collaboration.<ref>{{cite book | last=Kerrigan | first=John | authorlink=John Kerrigan (literary scholar) | chapter=Revision, Adaptation, and the Fool in ''King Lear'' | title=The Division of the Kingdoms: Shakespeare's Two Versions of King Lear | editor1-last=Taylor | editor1-first=Gary | editor1-link=Gary Taylor (scholar) | editor2-last=Warren | editor2-first=Michael | location=Oxford | publisher=Clarendon Press | year=1983 | pages=195–239 | isbn=978-0-19-812950-9}}</ref> The main reason Middleton's name is attached to the conjectured revision is because 4.1 calls for the use of two songs from ''[[The Witch (play)|The Witch]]'', a play by Middleton himself.<ref name="Brooke 37" /> However, Middleton's involvement with the play, and the notion of revision work itself, is not universally accepted. Two notable scholars who dissent from this theory are Jonathan Hope<ref>{{cite book | last=Hope | first=Jonathan | title=The Authorship of Shakespeare's Plays: A Socio-linguistic Study | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | year=1994 | pages=104–105 | isbn=978-0-521-03386-2}}</ref> and [[Brian Vickers (literary scholar)|Brian Vickers]].<ref>{{cite book | last=Vickers | first=Brian | authorlink=Brian Vickers (literary scholar) | title=Shakespeare, Co-Author: A Historical Study of Five Collaborative Plays | location=Oxford | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=2002 | pages=94–97 | isbn=978-0-19-926916-7}}</ref> :'''''Evidence''''': the play is closely connected to King James, and scholars are in general agreement that it is unlikely to have been written prior to his accession in 1603.
